description: Wireshark is a free and open source network packet sniffer and protocol analyzer. It is an invaluable tool for any network administrator who needs detailed visibility into the traffic on their network. It utilizes a packet capture utility or sniffer, which watches any traffic/communication that crosses the network adapter and writes it to a file and then the protocol analyzer interprets the raw data obtained by the sniffer and turns it into readable data. It also provides in-depth tools for isolating faults and troubleshooting failures.
name: Wireshark
subtitle: Network protocol analyzer

episodes.title: What is Wireshark?
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,110
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,110 --> 00:00:12,226
In this video series we're gonna take a
look at an amazing networking tool called

3
00:00:12,226 --> 00:00:12,900
Wireshark.

4
00:00:12,900 --> 00:00:16,210
A lot of people have heard about it,
not a lot of people have used it.

5
00:00:16,210 --> 00:00:19,570
We want to take some time to show you how
the product works, how you can use it,

6
00:00:19,570 --> 00:00:22,040
how you can take advantage of that to
help with your troubleshooting and

7
00:00:22,040 --> 00:00:24,510
just general network
gathering information.

8
00:00:24,510 --> 00:00:28,150
It is a terribly useful tool,
and it is completely free,

9
00:00:28,150 --> 00:00:29,780
that makes it really attractive.

10
00:00:29,780 --> 00:00:31,640
Let's start at the beginning though.

11
00:00:31,640 --> 00:00:33,370
What is Wireshark?

12
00:00:33,370 --> 00:00:35,030
Well, it's kind of hard to describe,

13
00:00:35,030 --> 00:00:37,900
because Wireshark is actually
several tools in one.

14
00:00:37,900 --> 00:00:40,860
It's a packet analyzer, it's a sniffer,

15
00:00:40,860 --> 00:00:43,770
it's a protocol analyzer,
a packet capture device.

16
00:00:43,770 --> 00:00:47,660
It's all these different things
wrapped into one big envelope.

17
00:00:47,660 --> 00:00:50,340
So let's tackle the pieces independently.

18
00:00:50,340 --> 00:00:57,110
We start with a packet capture utility,
sometimes called a sniffer.

19
00:00:57,110 --> 00:01:00,990
There are many different sniffers that
are out there from various vendors, but

20
00:01:00,990 --> 00:01:04,110
a sniffer pretty much works the same
way no matter who it's from.

21
00:01:04,110 --> 00:01:09,300
What a sniffer does, is it watches your
network card, and any traffic that crosses

22
00:01:09,300 --> 00:01:15,250
the network card, any communications,
telnet, SSH, TCP stuff, UDP stuff.

23
00:01:15,250 --> 00:01:18,950
Any communication across that
network card, it captures it and

24
00:01:18,950 --> 00:01:20,410
writes it to a file.

25
00:01:20,410 --> 00:01:24,800
It doesn't do anything with it,
it just gets it and saves it.

26
00:01:24,800 --> 00:01:29,890
On a normal computer, Linux,
Mac OS, Windows, doesn't matter, if

27
00:01:29,890 --> 00:01:34,970
it receives traffic that is not destined
for that computer, it throws it away.

28
00:01:34,970 --> 00:01:39,020
But a sniffer, or a packet capture
utility, won't throw it away.

29
00:01:39,020 --> 00:01:41,620
It'll hold it, it'll say all right,
I'll take a copy of that, and

30
00:01:41,620 --> 00:01:42,170
it'll write it down.

31
00:01:42,170 --> 00:01:47,340
All right, once you've got it written
down, you can then do stuff with it.

32
00:01:47,340 --> 00:01:51,230
One of the most popular packet capture
utilities that are out there is called

33
00:01:51,230 --> 00:01:52,310
TCP Dump.

34
00:01:52,310 --> 00:01:56,020
In the Unix and Linux world,
it's a command line utility you can run

35
00:01:56,020 --> 00:01:58,155
that'll just give you
an onscreen output or

36
00:01:58,155 --> 00:02:01,910
it can dump it to a file of all
the traffic hitting your network adapter.

37
00:02:01,910 --> 00:02:05,860
So if you want to see what's going on in
the network, it's a great way to do it.

38
00:02:05,860 --> 00:02:08,732
The problem though is it just
gives you this raw data and

39
00:02:08,732 --> 00:02:12,760
you then have to interpret it, and
the interpretation part is the hard part.

40
00:02:12,760 --> 00:02:15,670
That is what a protocol analyzer does.

41
00:02:15,670 --> 00:02:18,330
And again there's a number of
protocol analyzer out there,

42
00:02:18,330 --> 00:02:21,340
but what they all do is
pretty much the same.

43
00:02:21,340 --> 00:02:24,690
They take the packets that
were obtained by a sniffer And

44
00:02:24,690 --> 00:02:28,030
they transform them into something
that becomes human readable,

45
00:02:28,030 --> 00:02:30,770
something that we can look at and
recognize.

46
00:02:30,770 --> 00:02:35,230
Some of them go even further, and not just
translate into something we can recognize,

47
00:02:35,230 --> 00:02:40,280
but string it together to form patterns
and give us additional information.

48
00:02:40,280 --> 00:02:44,870
That is what a protocol analyzer does,
and the really advanced ones can

49
00:02:44,870 --> 00:02:47,640
break that data down in a way
that makes it super simple for

50
00:02:47,640 --> 00:02:49,510
us to interpret and to work with.

51
00:02:49,510 --> 00:02:51,251
And that's why when you go to like,

52
00:02:51,251 --> 00:02:54,410
WireShark's website they say
it's WireShark, go deeper.

53
00:02:54,410 --> 00:02:55,720
You get this data,

54
00:02:55,720 --> 00:02:59,110
you've got the information,
what can you extrapolate form it?

55
00:02:59,110 --> 00:03:01,460
What can you determine based on
the information that you've gathered?

56
00:03:01,460 --> 00:03:05,290
And you'll find there's actually a lot
stuff you can learn about your network.

57
00:03:05,290 --> 00:03:08,990
Now I started working with protocol
analyzers over 15 years ago, and

58
00:03:08,990 --> 00:03:13,700
back then, they were almost like voodoo
magic, and they were incredibly expensive.

59
00:03:13,700 --> 00:03:16,460
The one I used the most
commonly was a product,

60
00:03:16,460 --> 00:03:18,780
it's been bought out by a few
different companies, but back then,

61
00:03:18,780 --> 00:03:23,890
it was network general sniffer pro is what
it was called, and it cost about $15,000.

62
00:03:23,890 --> 00:03:26,530
It was very, very expensive.

63
00:03:26,530 --> 00:03:29,380
The company I worked for had purchased
the license for it, and we used it for

64
00:03:29,380 --> 00:03:31,220
troubleshooting all the time.

65
00:03:31,220 --> 00:03:35,210
It was a great product, but
that was a long time ago.

66
00:03:35,210 --> 00:03:37,560
Technologies have changed,
protocols have changed, and

67
00:03:37,560 --> 00:03:40,130
all the software packages
have had to keep up to date.

68
00:03:40,130 --> 00:03:42,480
Some of them have, some of them haven't.

69
00:03:42,480 --> 00:03:45,800
Utilities like tcpdump haven't
changed much over the years,

70
00:03:45,800 --> 00:03:47,740
they just dump the data out to a file.

71
00:03:47,740 --> 00:03:50,110
There's much they can advance on that.

72
00:03:50,110 --> 00:03:54,620
Other ones like Microsoft has something
called the Microsoft Network Monitor, and

73
00:03:54,620 --> 00:03:58,930
when it came out back in 1997,
it was fancy, it was nice.

74
00:03:58,930 --> 00:04:02,560
It could really do a lot of stuff,
but today,

75
00:04:02,560 --> 00:04:05,330
it's basically been abandoned by
Microsoft, they haven't updated it much.

76
00:04:05,330 --> 00:04:07,460
You can go to their site and
download it for free, but

77
00:04:07,460 --> 00:04:10,290
it's crippled compared to Wireshark.

78
00:04:10,290 --> 00:04:15,450
Wireshark is an open source protocol
analyzer that is actively being developed,

79
00:04:15,450 --> 00:04:17,550
getting new features every single week, so

80
00:04:17,550 --> 00:04:21,980
it's a very current system and
it's extremely powerful.

81
00:04:21,980 --> 00:04:25,050
It does pretty much
everything you could want.

82
00:04:25,050 --> 00:04:27,590
There are a few little things,
advanced type functionalities,

83
00:04:27,590 --> 00:04:31,800
they might not have, and that's why other
vendors still have the high end market.

84
00:04:31,800 --> 00:04:36,950
Companies like Fluke has
the network inspector, and

85
00:04:36,950 --> 00:04:39,850
that thing is incredibly expensive, but

86
00:04:39,850 --> 00:04:44,670
it does a very good job and it breaks down
your network and shows what's going on.

87
00:04:44,670 --> 00:04:49,760
So there is still a high end market for
that, but for me as a network engineer,

88
00:04:49,760 --> 00:04:52,770
I'm a big Cisco guy,
I work with networking equipment a lot.

89
00:04:52,770 --> 00:04:57,120
For me, I rarely use these utilities,
these high end utilities because I know

90
00:04:57,120 --> 00:05:02,280
that WireShark does everything that
I need so very powerful utility,

91
00:05:02,280 --> 00:05:08,030
very free and it will run on top of Linux,
Mac OS and Windows so it's multi platform.

92
00:05:08,030 --> 00:05:12,320
A lot of the high end stuff, like the
fluke stuff Will only run on windows, so

93
00:05:12,320 --> 00:05:15,620
there's limitations you have there, but
with Wireshark, you don't have that.

94
00:05:15,620 --> 00:05:17,220
Really, really cool stuff.

95
00:05:17,220 --> 00:05:20,670
Now, it's possible you've worked with
Wireshark before and don't know it..

96
00:05:20,670 --> 00:05:22,380
It used to have a different name.

97
00:05:22,380 --> 00:05:24,010
Wireshark was an open source product.

98
00:05:24,010 --> 00:05:27,820
It was developed by a network
engineer/developer in his spare time,

99
00:05:27,820 --> 00:05:32,030
and it was originally called ethereal,
or you'll here ether real, but

100
00:05:32,030 --> 00:05:33,670
it was ethereal.

101
00:05:33,670 --> 00:05:39,100
That was the original product, and when
he left the company he was working for,

102
00:05:39,100 --> 00:05:42,420
the name had been
trademarked by that company.

103
00:05:42,420 --> 00:05:45,640
He couldn't keep the name, so when he
left, he took his product with him, but

104
00:05:45,640 --> 00:05:48,650
he couldn't take the name until
we changed it to Wireshark.

105
00:05:48,650 --> 00:05:52,520
That was years ago now, so, anybody
getting started in IT in the last four or

106
00:05:52,520 --> 00:05:56,390
five years would probably only know it as
Wireshark, but every now and then you'll

107
00:05:56,390 --> 00:06:00,713
hear it referred to as a theory of
that old name that was attached to it.

108
00:06:00,713 --> 00:06:03,240
Now, it is open source, it's free,
you can go and download it,

109
00:06:03,240 --> 00:06:06,960
you can get the source code if you want
but, most of us just want the program.

110
00:06:06,960 --> 00:06:10,420
So, to get it you go to Wireshark's
website and you can download it and

111
00:06:10,420 --> 00:06:11,200
install from there.

112
00:06:11,200 --> 00:06:12,790
So they've got the get started and

113
00:06:12,790 --> 00:06:15,930
on there you'll see where it's got
the different OS's, so here I've got OSX,

114
00:06:15,930 --> 00:06:20,150
I've got Windows, Source Code,
you'll see other ones that are out there.

115
00:06:20,150 --> 00:06:25,050
And if you're running Linux it's likely
already been ported to your distro,

116
00:06:25,050 --> 00:06:27,470
you just need to check
the repositories for your distro.

117
00:06:27,470 --> 00:06:30,730
Scent OS and Red Hat have got
Wireshark in their distros already,

118
00:06:30,730 --> 00:06:35,680
so while it's not listed right here on
the website, it is available, all right.

119
00:06:35,680 --> 00:06:39,600
Now, Wireshark will watch
your network adapter, so

120
00:06:39,600 --> 00:06:43,070
whichever network adapters you have,
wireless or wired, and

121
00:06:43,070 --> 00:06:47,490
it will capture any of the data on
those interfaces and record it.

122
00:06:47,490 --> 00:06:50,540
You don't have a whole lot of system
requirements with Wireshark because it is

123
00:06:50,540 --> 00:06:54,650
really flexible and multi-platform, but
one thing you need to be aware of is,

124
00:06:54,650 --> 00:06:58,140
in order to capture traffic on a network
adapter that's not destined for your

125
00:06:58,140 --> 00:07:02,660
machine, the network adapter has to be
put into what's called promiscuous mode.

126
00:07:02,660 --> 00:07:05,940
Promiscuous mode means even though I'm
getting traffic that's not destined for

127
00:07:05,940 --> 00:07:08,270
me, I'm gonna to keep it.

128
00:07:08,270 --> 00:07:13,010
Some physical network adapters will block
that traffic before it even makes it to

129
00:07:13,010 --> 00:07:16,170
your OS, so the OS doesn't even
have a chance to capture it,

130
00:07:16,170 --> 00:07:18,260
it's already gone at that point.

131
00:07:18,260 --> 00:07:22,190
All right, so you need to make sure your
network adapter supports promiscuous mode.

132
00:07:22,190 --> 00:07:26,560
A lot of them do, so, it's not like
it's a rare feature or whatever.

133
00:07:26,560 --> 00:07:29,600
But if you find that no matter what you do
with Wireshark, you're just not getting

134
00:07:29,600 --> 00:07:33,190
any packets, well that might be your
indicator that you've got a problem there.

135
00:07:33,190 --> 00:07:37,920
But like I said most adapters do and when
you go to Wireshark's website, if you're

136
00:07:37,920 --> 00:07:41,400
wondering how they make money because it
is a free product, you'll see advertising.

137
00:07:41,400 --> 00:07:44,670
And a lot of times the advertisements
will center around network adapters, so

138
00:07:44,670 --> 00:07:49,090
like right here 802.11
packet capture adapters.

139
00:07:49,090 --> 00:07:52,180
You might already have a wireless
adapter in your system, but

140
00:07:52,180 --> 00:07:55,650
it might not support full promiscuous
mode on a wireless network.

141
00:07:55,650 --> 00:07:58,640
It might not be able to capture all that
data, so if you're trying to do something

142
00:07:58,640 --> 00:08:03,170
like a WEP key attack, or even WPA1
type attacks, you might not be able

143
00:08:03,170 --> 00:08:06,330
to pull them off with the wireless
adapter that's built in your system.

144
00:08:06,330 --> 00:08:10,290
So if you purchase one of these network
adapters, they specifically support

145
00:08:10,290 --> 00:08:13,120
the features you need,
you know you'll have that functionality.

146
00:08:13,120 --> 00:08:14,630
That's how Wire Shark makes their money.

147
00:08:14,630 --> 00:08:18,090
When you buy things like this,
they also do consulting, there's training,

148
00:08:18,090 --> 00:08:21,800
there is an official certification track
with Wire Shark you can go through.

149
00:08:21,800 --> 00:08:25,610
We're not tackling that here, we're just
gonna do general usage of the product, but

150
00:08:25,610 --> 00:08:28,550
there's various ways like that
that they generate their revenue.

151
00:08:28,550 --> 00:08:30,900
So don't think that they're
shady because it's free,

152
00:08:30,900 --> 00:08:32,850
they just make their money other ways.

153
00:08:32,850 --> 00:08:34,090
It's a great resource and

154
00:08:34,090 --> 00:08:38,090
it's really a gift to the networking
community to even have this available.

155
00:08:38,090 --> 00:08:39,012
It's incredibly powerful.

156
00:08:39,012 --> 00:08:42,540
All right, so,
that's pretty much all we need for

157
00:08:42,540 --> 00:08:45,080
our high level interview
here with Wire Shark.

158
00:08:45,080 --> 00:08:47,630
If you're curious,
you can browse through their website,

159
00:08:47,630 --> 00:08:52,050
it's just wireshark.org, and
they've got a Get Acquainted menu up top.

160
00:08:52,050 --> 00:08:55,580
And you can read about it, you can learn
about the product and download it.

161
00:08:55,580 --> 00:08:58,580
At the end of the day,
it is an open source product.

162
00:08:58,580 --> 00:09:00,170
Here's all the different developers.

163
00:09:00,170 --> 00:09:02,240
It's a neat program and

164
00:09:02,240 --> 00:09:05,280
we'll see how to use it as we go
through these series of videos.

165
00:09:05,280 --> 00:09:09,340
So stay tuned for those as we follow
up with how to get it installed,

166
00:09:09,340 --> 00:09:11,690
how to work with it, and
how to interpret our data.

167
00:09:11,690 --> 00:09:13,800
So it's gonna be a whole series on that.

168
00:09:13,800 --> 00:09:17,075
Make sure you stay tuned.

169
00:09:17,075 --> 00:09:21,644
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Installing Wireshark
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,111 --> 00:00:08,280
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,280 --> 00:00:10,566
All right, so
if we're gonna use Wireshark,

3
00:00:10,566 --> 00:00:12,590
we probably need to get it installed.

4
00:00:12,590 --> 00:00:14,720
Fortunately that's a pretty easy process.

5
00:00:14,720 --> 00:00:17,900
To install Wireshark, we just go to
their website, wireshark.org, and

6
00:00:17,900 --> 00:00:21,050
they've got a great big download
button right on their homepage.

7
00:00:21,050 --> 00:00:23,160
So you'll see it right
here at the top left.

8
00:00:23,160 --> 00:00:26,170
When you click on it, it'll try and
figure out what operating system you're

9
00:00:26,170 --> 00:00:28,330
running and
give you the recommendation, right?

10
00:00:28,330 --> 00:00:32,170
So it sees that I'm running
a 64-bit version of Windows, and so

11
00:00:32,170 --> 00:00:34,180
it's got that installer highlighted for
me.

12
00:00:34,180 --> 00:00:36,015
You can download the other
versions if you want.

13
00:00:36,015 --> 00:00:39,400
There's the 32-bit version,
there's the Mac OS versions.

14
00:00:39,400 --> 00:00:41,210
We've got source code.

15
00:00:41,210 --> 00:00:42,500
If you're on the Linux or

16
00:00:42,500 --> 00:00:46,980
Unix machine, you can certainly download
the source code and compile it from code.

17
00:00:46,980 --> 00:00:48,710
It's a pretty big undertaking.

18
00:00:48,710 --> 00:00:51,740
So you're normally better off
looking to the repositories for

19
00:00:51,740 --> 00:00:52,863
your distro, all right?

20
00:00:52,863 --> 00:00:56,169
So if you're running CentOS or Red Hat,
you can check the repositories and

21
00:00:56,169 --> 00:00:58,490
there's usually a Wireshark
build already there.

22
00:00:58,490 --> 00:01:00,870
You can just install from a package.

23
00:01:00,870 --> 00:01:03,240
Now there is this
Windows Portable Edition.

24
00:01:03,240 --> 00:01:06,460
That's a special one that's
designed to run from a USB key.

25
00:01:06,460 --> 00:01:08,370
So if you wanna run
Wireshark on a machine, but

26
00:01:08,370 --> 00:01:11,960
you don't wanna actually install it,
you can use the portable edition.

27
00:01:11,960 --> 00:01:14,150
It won't write any
entries to your registry.

28
00:01:14,150 --> 00:01:16,750
It doesn't write any temporary
files on the C drive.

29
00:01:16,750 --> 00:01:19,290
It stores everything right
there on that USB key, so

30
00:01:19,290 --> 00:01:22,550
you can tote it from machine to machine,
all right?

31
00:01:22,550 --> 00:01:25,700
Well, once you figure out which
version you're gonna get, go ahead and

32
00:01:25,700 --> 00:01:26,450
download it.

33
00:01:26,450 --> 00:01:28,550
Now the download, it runs kinda slow.

34
00:01:28,550 --> 00:01:31,450
I was originally gonna download it during
the show, but it took many minutes.

35
00:01:32,500 --> 00:01:37,060
Wireshark is a free product, and so they
don't have a ton of bandwidth available.

36
00:01:37,060 --> 00:01:37,910
But you'll go ahead and

37
00:01:37,910 --> 00:01:41,820
download it, and I downloaded it and
saved it to my desktop right here.

38
00:01:41,820 --> 00:01:43,350
To get it installed we just fire it up.

39
00:01:44,490 --> 00:01:45,730
We'll run that.

40
00:01:45,730 --> 00:01:47,490
It just prompted me for
administrative privileges.

41
00:01:47,490 --> 00:01:50,580
You guys didn't see that cuz my
screen share doesn't show it.

42
00:01:50,580 --> 00:01:53,230
But here we are,
it's just this simple startup wizard.

43
00:01:53,230 --> 00:01:54,700
Now, if you're like me,

44
00:01:54,700 --> 00:01:58,210
you might already have Wireshark
installed with other products.

45
00:01:58,210 --> 00:02:01,180
Because it is free, it sometimes
gets packaged with other things.

46
00:02:01,180 --> 00:02:05,490
I did a show yesterday on a product
called GNS3 that had Wireshark built in.

47
00:02:05,490 --> 00:02:08,020
So, you might see that
it's already installed.

48
00:02:08,020 --> 00:02:09,980
And if that's the case,
it'll prompt you and say,

49
00:02:09,980 --> 00:02:12,490
do you wanna uninstall
the other version first?

50
00:02:12,490 --> 00:02:14,050
So you might see that.

51
00:02:14,050 --> 00:02:16,500
If this is your first time though,
you'll see this wizard.

52
00:02:16,500 --> 00:02:18,290
And we just walk through and
do the install.

53
00:02:18,290 --> 00:02:22,510
For the most part, the only decisions we
have to make here are what path we wanna

54
00:02:22,510 --> 00:02:26,990
install Wireshark into, and a couple
of decisions built around WinPcap that

55
00:02:26,990 --> 00:02:28,830
we'll see here in just a moment,
all right?

56
00:02:28,830 --> 00:02:31,170
You'll see that it's
gonna install Wireshark.

57
00:02:31,170 --> 00:02:32,550
That's the main thing that I care about.

58
00:02:32,550 --> 00:02:34,734
And there's some other
components that it'll bring in,

59
00:02:34,734 --> 00:02:38,240
like the text-based Wireshark, tshark.

60
00:02:38,240 --> 00:02:41,560
You've also got some other tools and
utilities that are gonna come in,

61
00:02:41,560 --> 00:02:44,340
most of these just for interpreting
the data that we're gathering.

62
00:02:44,340 --> 00:02:48,810
All right, then it's gonna ask
where I wanna create my icons and

63
00:02:48,810 --> 00:02:49,620
all that good stuff.

64
00:02:49,620 --> 00:02:51,640
I'll just go with the defaults here.

65
00:02:51,640 --> 00:02:55,620
And it's gonna associate the file
extensions that Wireshark creates, so

66
00:02:55,620 --> 00:02:58,093
I'll go with the defaults there,
all right?

67
00:02:58,093 --> 00:03:00,450
The file path doesn't really matter to me.

68
00:03:00,450 --> 00:03:02,860
I'll go with the default
of C:/programfiles.

69
00:03:02,860 --> 00:03:05,090
You might install your software
to different directories.

70
00:03:05,090 --> 00:03:05,830
Not a big deal there.

71
00:03:07,100 --> 00:03:08,790
All right, now here's the important one.

72
00:03:08,790 --> 00:03:11,160
It's offering to install WinPcap.

73
00:03:11,160 --> 00:03:12,320
Now what is that?

74
00:03:12,320 --> 00:03:15,120
That's the Windows packet capture utility.

75
00:03:15,120 --> 00:03:17,420
If you're installing Wireshark on Linux,

76
00:03:17,420 --> 00:03:20,960
it's already got a packet
capture utility built into it.

77
00:03:20,960 --> 00:03:21,970
It doesn't need this, right?

78
00:03:21,970 --> 00:03:24,790
And if you're installing on Mac OS,
well it's based on BSD.

79
00:03:24,790 --> 00:03:27,620
It also has its own
packet capture utility.

80
00:03:27,620 --> 00:03:29,280
But in Windows we don't.

81
00:03:29,280 --> 00:03:33,860
In Windows, your network adapter will
reject traffic that's not destined for

82
00:03:33,860 --> 00:03:35,210
your machine by default.

83
00:03:35,210 --> 00:03:39,460
If the physical adapter doesn't do it,
Windows will do it.

84
00:03:39,460 --> 00:03:41,340
Well WinPcap overrides that.

85
00:03:41,340 --> 00:03:45,740
It goes in and it says, let's allow
the gathering of packets on that interface

86
00:03:45,740 --> 00:03:48,130
regardless of whether they're destined for
us or not.

87
00:03:48,130 --> 00:03:50,730
So it's the packet capture driver.

88
00:03:50,730 --> 00:03:54,230
It basically steps in and
attaches itself to your network adapter.

89
00:03:54,230 --> 00:03:58,470
Now, when you install it,
it will reset your network adapter.

90
00:03:58,470 --> 00:04:01,370
So if you're in the middle of something,
you'll get disconnected.

91
00:04:01,370 --> 00:04:04,240
So like if I'm in the middle
of sharing my screen out,

92
00:04:04,240 --> 00:04:05,940
it's gonna disconnect us, all right?

93
00:04:05,940 --> 00:04:09,820
Well, now I've already got WinPcap
installed on my machine, so

94
00:04:09,820 --> 00:04:11,160
I don't have to install it here.

95
00:04:11,160 --> 00:04:13,020
You can uncheck it if
you've already got it.

96
00:04:13,020 --> 00:04:14,650
How do you know if you have it?

97
00:04:14,650 --> 00:04:16,141
Well, just check your system, right?

98
00:04:16,141 --> 00:04:19,285
If we go into our programs
here to see what's installed,

99
00:04:19,285 --> 00:04:22,362
we can look at all the junk
installed on our machine, and

100
00:04:22,362 --> 00:04:26,241
you'll probably find WinPcap right
there if you've already got it.

101
00:04:26,241 --> 00:04:30,360
I'm running 4.1.3, which is exactly
what's packaged here, all right?

102
00:04:30,360 --> 00:04:33,380
If you don't have WinPcap,
just leave that checked, and

103
00:04:33,380 --> 00:04:34,780
that'll be the next part of the install.

104
00:04:34,780 --> 00:04:35,840
It'll install it.

105
00:04:35,840 --> 00:04:37,370
There's not really any options with it.

106
00:04:37,370 --> 00:04:39,280
You pick a folder and
you hit next a bunch of times.

107
00:04:39,280 --> 00:04:41,620
So there's not anything
too exciting there.

108
00:04:41,620 --> 00:04:43,590
I'll uncheck that and hit install.

109
00:04:43,590 --> 00:04:45,980
So here it goes, doing the installer.

110
00:04:45,980 --> 00:04:49,570
Now if I had chose to do WinPcap,
my adapter would be about to reset, and

111
00:04:49,570 --> 00:04:52,550
my desktop would freeze,
but we'll be okay here.

112
00:04:52,550 --> 00:04:53,922
It's gonna install.

113
00:04:53,922 --> 00:04:56,760
Now, Wireshark is written, and

114
00:04:56,760 --> 00:05:00,310
it's basically built on
a lot of Python and a lot of

115
00:05:00,310 --> 00:05:03,840
open programming languages to make it
easy to port to multiple platforms.

116
00:05:03,840 --> 00:05:05,570
So you'll see it copy a lot of files.

117
00:05:05,570 --> 00:05:09,070
There's a lot of stuff that gets
copied over as part of the software.

118
00:05:09,070 --> 00:05:12,180
But once it's in place,
there's really just one icon forest and

119
00:05:12,180 --> 00:05:13,590
it becomes a lot easier to use.

120
00:05:14,620 --> 00:05:17,100
We'll go ahead and hit Next here,
and finish that up.

121
00:05:17,100 --> 00:05:19,050
And now, I've got Wireshark on my machine.

122
00:05:19,050 --> 00:05:20,710
If I go under my start menu,

123
00:05:20,710 --> 00:05:23,060
I should be able to find a new
Wireshark entry in here.

124
00:05:23,060 --> 00:05:24,200
Here we go.

125
00:05:24,200 --> 00:05:27,940
I've got Wireshark,
as well as the Wireshark 2 preview.

126
00:05:27,940 --> 00:05:30,890
That was one of the options
in the install that I chose.

127
00:05:30,890 --> 00:05:32,936
I installed Wireshark version 1.12.

128
00:05:32,936 --> 00:05:36,580
Wireshark 2.0 is on the horizon, right?

129
00:05:36,580 --> 00:05:39,130
So they give you the preview
version of that.

130
00:05:39,130 --> 00:05:42,630
But for this series I'm gonna
focus on the stable version.

131
00:05:42,630 --> 00:05:46,392
When 2.0 comes out,
we'll do another video series to cover it.

132
00:05:46,392 --> 00:05:49,750
Once Wireshark's installed though,
you can fire it up and there it is.

133
00:05:49,750 --> 00:05:52,180
It's up, it's running, and it's happy.

134
00:05:52,180 --> 00:05:56,660
Now, when you installed WinPcap,
it asked you whether or

135
00:05:56,660 --> 00:06:00,750
not you wanted it to start when
Windows started, all right?

136
00:06:00,750 --> 00:06:04,855
Again, in Linux and Mac OS you don't
have to worry about it, but in Windows,

137
00:06:04,855 --> 00:06:07,720
WinPcap has to be running for
Wireshark to run.

138
00:06:07,720 --> 00:06:10,960
Wireshark won't work if WinPcap
isn't running, all right?

139
00:06:10,960 --> 00:06:14,580
If you don't remember what option you
chose when you ran the installer,

140
00:06:14,580 --> 00:06:15,630
you can double check that.

141
00:06:15,630 --> 00:06:18,306
I'm gonna close out of Wireshark.

142
00:06:18,306 --> 00:06:22,410
And in Windows,
I'm gonna go in my Services tool.

143
00:06:22,410 --> 00:06:25,250
So you can just use your search
box to type in services.

144
00:06:26,650 --> 00:06:28,980
And then run the wrong thing.

145
00:06:28,980 --> 00:06:29,690
There we go.

146
00:06:29,690 --> 00:06:30,210
We want this one.

147
00:06:30,210 --> 00:06:31,240
It has the little gears on it.

148
00:06:31,240 --> 00:06:35,580
So I'm gonna go into Services, and WinPcap
actually installs itself as a service.

149
00:06:35,580 --> 00:06:36,970
And so you'll find it in here.

150
00:06:36,970 --> 00:06:40,070
It's called something or another.

151
00:06:40,070 --> 00:06:44,230
But basically it has to be up and running,
and when you installed it, the packet

152
00:06:44,230 --> 00:06:48,280
capture utility should have set itself
to automatically start with the system.

153
00:06:48,280 --> 00:06:52,110
And if it didn't, well you could come in
and manually start it when you wanted.

154
00:06:52,110 --> 00:06:54,520
I'm trying to remember
exactly what it's called.

155
00:06:54,520 --> 00:06:56,230
It's buried in here somewhere.

156
00:06:56,230 --> 00:06:59,940
Mine's set to automatically start,
so I'm okay, but

157
00:06:59,940 --> 00:07:01,692
I did wanna show you guys that service.

158
00:07:01,692 --> 00:07:05,930
Let's see,
I probably looked over it five times now.

159
00:07:07,090 --> 00:07:10,550
But basically it installs itself as
a service in here, and you can start and

160
00:07:10,550 --> 00:07:14,000
stop it whenever you want,
based on what your needs are.

161
00:07:16,360 --> 00:07:20,457
It'll probably have some name that's stuck
at the beginning that's making me not

162
00:07:20,457 --> 00:07:22,950
find it, but it is in here somewhere.

163
00:07:22,950 --> 00:07:26,526
All right, the other place that you'll
see it is actually attached to your

164
00:07:26,526 --> 00:07:30,580
network adapter, so that's the other
place where it needs to be activated.

165
00:07:30,580 --> 00:07:35,320
If I go into my Network and
Sharing Center, let me go into that.

166
00:07:35,320 --> 00:07:39,260
If I go into my Network and
Sharing Center, and I go into

167
00:07:39,260 --> 00:07:43,370
Change Adapter Settings, you can pull up
the properties of any of your adapters and

168
00:07:43,370 --> 00:07:47,600
you'll see that the WinPcap has
kind of attached itself there too.

169
00:07:47,600 --> 00:07:51,380
So it's in a few different places that
you'll see it bound to your system.

170
00:07:51,380 --> 00:07:55,570
So it actually gets in here and
attaches to the network adapter.

171
00:07:55,570 --> 00:07:56,880
I'm not seeing the net list either.

172
00:07:59,200 --> 00:08:01,310
I said I had WinPcap
installed on this machine.

173
00:08:01,310 --> 00:08:02,509
Maybe I don't.
[LAUGH] Well,

174
00:08:02,509 --> 00:08:07,107
the easiest way to find out there is to
see whether or not it's working, right?

175
00:08:07,107 --> 00:08:11,309
You can quickly and easily see whether
WinPcap is functioning by firing up

176
00:08:11,309 --> 00:08:14,300
Wireshark, and
pulling up a list of your adapters.

177
00:08:14,300 --> 00:08:14,850
So I'll do that.

178
00:08:14,850 --> 00:08:16,730
I'll fire up Wireshark.

179
00:08:16,730 --> 00:08:19,380
And you'll see your list
of adaptors over here.

180
00:08:19,380 --> 00:08:23,860
But if you click on this button that says
Interface List, it'll list your adaptors.

181
00:08:23,860 --> 00:08:26,360
And see how you've got this
packet information right here?

182
00:08:26,360 --> 00:08:29,330
It's showing you whether
it's seeing any packets.

183
00:08:29,330 --> 00:08:33,260
If WinPcap is functional,
you'll see these numbers going up.

184
00:08:33,260 --> 00:08:36,670
If it's not functional,
you'll just see all zeros, right?

185
00:08:36,670 --> 00:08:39,450
Now most of mine show all zeros cuz those
network adapters aren't plugged in.

186
00:08:39,450 --> 00:08:41,930
I'm not connected to
a WiFi network right now.

187
00:08:41,930 --> 00:08:44,710
This Local Area Connection 8
is actually a fake connection.

188
00:08:44,710 --> 00:08:47,380
So a lot of these are just
not even connected.

189
00:08:47,380 --> 00:08:48,530
But my real connection,

190
00:08:48,530 --> 00:08:52,100
this ethernet jack,
I see packets traveling over it, right?

191
00:08:52,100 --> 00:08:55,650
That's my indicator right there, so
I know that WinPcap is operational and

192
00:08:55,650 --> 00:08:56,850
running fine, all right?

193
00:08:56,850 --> 00:08:59,510
So just keep that in mind
when you do the install that

194
00:08:59,510 --> 00:09:01,240
WinPcap is kind of
an important part of this.

195
00:09:02,350 --> 00:09:03,080
All right.

196
00:09:03,080 --> 00:09:05,200
So that's getting Wireshark installed.

197
00:09:05,200 --> 00:09:06,710
Not a big deal, right?

198
00:09:06,710 --> 00:09:09,060
Once it's installed, we need to use it.

199
00:09:09,060 --> 00:09:11,700
So that's what our next set of
videos are gonna be covering.

200
00:09:11,700 --> 00:09:15,039
So stay tuned and make sure you check out
those as we see how to capture our data,

201
00:09:15,039 --> 00:09:16,570
and then how to interpret our data.

202
00:09:16,570 --> 00:09:18,410
It'll be a lot of fun.

203
00:09:18,410 --> 00:09:24,689
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Installing on OS X
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:09,090
[SOUND].

2
00:00:09,090 --> 00:00:13,460
So in a previous video we did
installing Wireshark on a Windows PC.

3
00:00:13,460 --> 00:00:17,460
Now I wanna take a look at installing
Wireshark on a Mac OS machine.

4
00:00:17,460 --> 00:00:20,733
You might have an Apple laptop,
they're very common, and

5
00:00:20,733 --> 00:00:22,840
Wireshark will run just fine.

6
00:00:22,840 --> 00:00:26,640
The Wireshark installation on a Mac,
though, is a little bit more complex,

7
00:00:26,640 --> 00:00:28,940
I suppose, than on the Windows side.

8
00:00:28,940 --> 00:00:32,430
And the reason is the version
of Wireshark written for

9
00:00:32,430 --> 00:00:34,770
Mac wasn't natively written for the Mac.

10
00:00:34,770 --> 00:00:39,020
It was actually written for Linux and
then ported from Linux over to the Mac.

11
00:00:39,020 --> 00:00:42,600
And that means there's a few little
things we have to do before we can get

12
00:00:42,600 --> 00:00:44,570
Wireshark installed.

13
00:00:44,570 --> 00:00:46,830
Now a lot of it isn't called
out on the Wireshark page.

14
00:00:46,830 --> 00:00:51,352
And if you go to the Wireshark webpage and
you go to Download, it'll detect that

15
00:00:51,352 --> 00:00:56,010
you're running Mac OS and so you'll see
where it's got the different OSes listed

16
00:00:56,010 --> 00:01:01,540
here, and I've got OS X 10.6 and later
Intel 64-bit, that's what I'm running.

17
00:01:01,540 --> 00:01:02,330
So it's right there.

18
00:01:02,330 --> 00:01:03,190
I see it.

19
00:01:03,190 --> 00:01:05,950
I can jump in there and do the install.

20
00:01:05,950 --> 00:01:09,220
But, the graphical user interface

21
00:01:09,220 --> 00:01:12,850
is all written in a way that expects
you to have a Linux machine.

22
00:01:12,850 --> 00:01:17,750
And in Linux, you have the X-1-1,
or X11, windows manager.

23
00:01:17,750 --> 00:01:19,490
On a Mac, we don't have that.

24
00:01:19,490 --> 00:01:22,330
We've got the Aqua windows manager and
all that stuff, so

25
00:01:22,330 --> 00:01:24,090
it's a different window manager.

26
00:01:24,090 --> 00:01:27,310
So before we can install the Wireshark,

27
00:01:27,310 --> 00:01:28,820
well, I guess you could
install it right now.

28
00:01:28,820 --> 00:01:29,900
It's just not gonna work.

29
00:01:29,900 --> 00:01:35,460
Before we can get it to work, we need to
install an X window manager on our Mac.

30
00:01:35,460 --> 00:01:38,050
That doesn't mean we're gonna lose
the interface that we've already got.

31
00:01:38,050 --> 00:01:40,417
Everything stays the same, it's just for

32
00:01:40,417 --> 00:01:43,250
Wireshark it'll have
this alternate interface.

33
00:01:43,250 --> 00:01:46,590
There's several different X windows
managers that are out there.

34
00:01:46,590 --> 00:01:50,130
The best one in my opinion
is one called XQuartz.

35
00:01:50,130 --> 00:01:54,745
If you go to this website right here,
www.macosforge.org,

36
00:01:54,745 --> 00:02:00,400
when you go to that website they've
got several projects listed here.

37
00:02:00,400 --> 00:02:02,330
One of them is way down
here at the bottom.

38
00:02:02,330 --> 00:02:06,180
It's the XQuartz program and
so I'm gonna fire that up.

39
00:02:06,180 --> 00:02:07,920
And it'll take you the XQuartz page.

40
00:02:07,920 --> 00:02:11,031
And it's just a port of the x.org or

41
00:02:11,031 --> 00:02:16,750
the X11 window manager over to
the Mac OS environment, right?

42
00:02:16,750 --> 00:02:17,710
So you can download it.

43
00:02:17,710 --> 00:02:22,150
It's got XQuartz 2.77.DMG,
that's our installation file.

44
00:02:22,150 --> 00:02:25,690
You know, my mouse is not quite pointing
at what I'm talking about there, is it?

45
00:02:25,690 --> 00:02:26,920
But anyhow, it's right there.

46
00:02:26,920 --> 00:02:29,560
We can download it, and
we'll have it ready for us.

47
00:02:30,590 --> 00:02:34,590
So to get this installed on a Mac, we
need to download that file, that's first.

48
00:02:34,590 --> 00:02:38,170
And we need to go ahead and
download the Wireshark installer.

49
00:02:38,170 --> 00:02:39,670
So we'll download that DMG too.

50
00:02:39,670 --> 00:02:42,620
And I downloaded those before the show,
so I've got them sitting right here.

51
00:02:43,620 --> 00:02:45,170
Now in order to install XQuartz,

52
00:02:45,170 --> 00:02:48,220
you will need to be an administrator
on your machine, right?

53
00:02:48,220 --> 00:02:49,580
It needs to get installed.

54
00:02:49,580 --> 00:02:50,810
So if I open up that DMG,

55
00:02:50,810 --> 00:02:55,580
it's gonna connect up and
it'll have a package that I can install.

56
00:02:55,580 --> 00:02:57,860
You know, if there's an app where you
don't have to be an administrator,

57
00:02:57,860 --> 00:03:01,300
it's one of those where you just drag it
and drop it into your application folder.

58
00:03:01,300 --> 00:03:05,730
But in this case, XQuartz has some display
driver settings inside of it, and so

59
00:03:05,730 --> 00:03:07,360
it's got to be an installation package.

60
00:03:07,360 --> 00:03:09,390
That's why we've got to
be an administrator.

61
00:03:09,390 --> 00:03:11,160
So I'm gonna fire that up.

62
00:03:11,160 --> 00:03:13,400
There's not really any options in here.

63
00:03:13,400 --> 00:03:17,790
When we go through and set it up, it's
basically just clicking Continue a bunch.

64
00:03:17,790 --> 00:03:22,300
So I'll hit Continue on my read me,
I'll hit Continue on the license.

65
00:03:23,820 --> 00:03:26,580
For the installation type,
there's no choice, right?

66
00:03:26,580 --> 00:03:30,400
It's just a standard install so
I'll hit that and then it's gonna install.

67
00:03:30,400 --> 00:03:32,850
Now it's prompting me for
my administrator permissions

68
00:03:34,400 --> 00:03:37,380
because it's gotta install some
system files as part of it.

69
00:03:37,380 --> 00:03:39,630
So it's gonna get installed and
then we'll have it.

70
00:03:41,230 --> 00:03:44,250
Once that's done I'll turn around and
I'll do the same thing for Wireshark.

71
00:03:44,250 --> 00:03:47,670
I'm gonna click on that DMG and
that'll fire up and

72
00:03:47,670 --> 00:03:50,080
I'll get an installation
package there too.

73
00:03:50,080 --> 00:03:53,970
Now, Wireshark is also not just one of
those simple drag and drop ones because it

74
00:03:53,970 --> 00:03:58,190
has to load some packet driver software,
but it'll do it as part of the install.

75
00:03:58,190 --> 00:04:00,740
And then it'll be done too, right?

76
00:04:00,740 --> 00:04:02,610
So the installation's pretty
straightforward so far.

77
00:04:02,610 --> 00:04:04,070
The big difference between here and

78
00:04:04,070 --> 00:04:08,500
a Windows machine is having to install
that X.org desktop environment, right?

79
00:04:08,500 --> 00:04:10,170
So once we've got that,

80
00:04:10,170 --> 00:04:14,450
the first time we launch Wireshark it's
gonna ask where the X environment is, and

81
00:04:14,450 --> 00:04:18,770
we'll have to point it to XQuartz so it'll
know where to find it, so we'll do that.

82
00:04:18,770 --> 00:04:22,100
After that, it's installed and
you run Wireshark like normal, so

83
00:04:22,100 --> 00:04:23,780
it's really not that bad.

84
00:04:23,780 --> 00:04:26,898
Well, we'll give it just a moment here,
it's telling me it's about a minute.

85
00:04:26,898 --> 00:04:31,400
Installing this, XQuartz is actually
really small so I'm not quite sure why

86
00:04:31,400 --> 00:04:35,830
it's taking so long, but like most
Linux and UNIX programs it's made up of

87
00:04:35,830 --> 00:04:39,510
tons of very small files and so
copying those can take a while.

88
00:04:39,510 --> 00:04:42,870
I'm on an SSD though, so
it should be pretty fast.

89
00:04:42,870 --> 00:04:44,770
I'll see how patient I can be.

90
00:04:44,770 --> 00:04:48,230
While I'm waiting on that, actually, here
I'll just move that off to the side so

91
00:04:48,230 --> 00:04:50,150
it's kind of doing its thing.

92
00:04:50,150 --> 00:04:53,758
While we're waiting on that, I'll go ahead
and get ready for the Wireshark install.

93
00:04:53,758 --> 00:04:57,530
If I double-click and
mount that DMG you'll see it right here,

94
00:04:57,530 --> 00:05:00,950
it's got a packaged install
just like XQuartz did.

95
00:05:00,950 --> 00:05:04,420
And it's got a read me you can go
through but we wanna do that install.

96
00:05:04,420 --> 00:05:06,910
The order that you install
these in doesn't really matter.

97
00:05:06,910 --> 00:05:08,740
I could have installed Wireshark first and

98
00:05:08,740 --> 00:05:13,940
then installed XQuartz afterwards, it's
not like one is dependent on the other.

99
00:05:13,940 --> 00:05:16,399
So I'm gonna go ahead and
start the install for Wireshark.

100
00:05:17,620 --> 00:05:18,390
And we'll move forward.

101
00:05:18,390 --> 00:05:22,140
It's just gonna give me their licensing
agreement, which I'll sign off on.

102
00:05:22,140 --> 00:05:24,306
And it's gonna ask where I wanna install,

103
00:05:24,306 --> 00:05:28,050
and it's giving me the choice to change
the install location if I want to.

104
00:05:28,050 --> 00:05:28,960
I don't.

105
00:05:28,960 --> 00:05:30,468
I'll leave it be, all right?

106
00:05:30,468 --> 00:05:33,658
And then, well,
now it's gonna tell me to wait.

107
00:05:33,658 --> 00:05:36,766
So now [LAUGH] I'm gonna wait for this
guy to finish before the second one can

108
00:05:36,766 --> 00:05:40,250
finish, so we'll give it a second while
it finishes and then we'll pick back up.

109
00:05:40,250 --> 00:05:44,210
So let's just take a quick time out and
we'll be back as soon as this is done.

110
00:05:44,210 --> 00:05:52,129
[SOUND].

111
00:05:52,129 --> 00:05:54,482
All right, so
both the installers just finished,

112
00:05:54,482 --> 00:05:57,500
so I'm just gonna hit Close on those,
and get them out of the way.

113
00:05:57,500 --> 00:06:00,754
Now, when it installed,
it did install some system preferences and

114
00:06:00,754 --> 00:06:02,717
things like that, so those are in place,

115
00:06:02,717 --> 00:06:05,710
but I wanna show you where
the applications actually ended up.

116
00:06:05,710 --> 00:06:08,770
I'm done with these DMGs, so
I'll just get those out of there.

117
00:06:08,770 --> 00:06:11,600
If we go into our Applications
folder we'll see we have a new

118
00:06:11,600 --> 00:06:16,616
application in here, which is Wireshark,
and it'll be located right there.

119
00:06:16,616 --> 00:06:19,900
The other thing that I want to point out
is inside of your Applications folder,

120
00:06:19,900 --> 00:06:24,810
there's a Utilities folder and
inside of Utilities, you'll find X11.

121
00:06:26,220 --> 00:06:30,590
That is the XQuartz software
that we just installed.

122
00:06:30,590 --> 00:06:33,560
So it's not called XQuartz,
it's called X11.

123
00:06:33,560 --> 00:06:35,630
And that can be a little bit confusing.

124
00:06:35,630 --> 00:06:40,620
When we launch Wireshark the first time,
it's gonna ask you where that

125
00:06:40,620 --> 00:06:44,440
X windowed environment is, and you'll
have to point to that file right there.

126
00:06:44,440 --> 00:06:47,280
So we just need to know where it's
located, inside of Applications and

127
00:06:47,280 --> 00:06:47,860
Utilities.

128
00:06:49,130 --> 00:06:51,820
So I'm gonna go ahead and
fire up Wireshark, and

129
00:06:51,820 --> 00:06:52,890
we'll just get that launched.

130
00:06:52,890 --> 00:06:56,050
Now I use X applications like
these pretty often and so

131
00:06:56,050 --> 00:06:58,590
it may have cached that to see that
I've already got the environment.

132
00:06:58,590 --> 00:07:01,920
If you already have XQuartz for
some reason, it may already be there.

133
00:07:01,920 --> 00:07:05,810
But otherwise,
it should launch up and prompt us.

134
00:07:05,810 --> 00:07:08,010
Now, I've seen this before.

135
00:07:08,010 --> 00:07:11,470
I've launched Wireshark and it's not
prompting me, it's just sitting here.

136
00:07:11,470 --> 00:07:12,580
It's sitting here doing nothing.

137
00:07:12,580 --> 00:07:15,110
And I can see I've got
Wireshark up here in my menu.

138
00:07:15,110 --> 00:07:16,920
So I know it launched.

139
00:07:16,920 --> 00:07:19,150
It's just not working.

140
00:07:19,150 --> 00:07:21,630
I've seen this before when
you launch Wireshark and

141
00:07:21,630 --> 00:07:24,080
you haven't launched XQuartz prior to it.

142
00:07:24,080 --> 00:07:26,890
So I'm gonna go ahead and
quit out of Wireshark.

143
00:07:26,890 --> 00:07:30,710
And I'll launch XQuartz first, and
so I'll go under Utilities here and

144
00:07:30,710 --> 00:07:33,360
fire up XQuartz, which we only
have to do this the first time.

145
00:07:33,360 --> 00:07:36,330
In the future we'll be able to
launch Wireshark by itself.

146
00:07:36,330 --> 00:07:38,050
But I'm gonna go ahead and
launch XQuartz and

147
00:07:38,050 --> 00:07:41,390
just make sure that it doesn't have
anything pending inside of it.

148
00:07:41,390 --> 00:07:42,490
And it seems to be fine.

149
00:07:42,490 --> 00:07:43,490
So I've just launched it.

150
00:07:43,490 --> 00:07:46,580
I can see I've got XQuartz
up here in my menu and

151
00:07:46,580 --> 00:07:48,190
everything seems to be fine there.

152
00:07:48,190 --> 00:07:48,830
All right.

153
00:07:48,830 --> 00:07:50,380
Now I'll go and relaunch Wireshark.

154
00:07:53,460 --> 00:07:55,090
And we'll fire it up.

155
00:07:55,090 --> 00:07:57,430
And it should see that environment and
tie into it.

156
00:07:57,430 --> 00:08:02,130
All right, it looks like it is not picking
it up, which is going to be a problem,

157
00:08:02,130 --> 00:08:04,790
isn't it?

158
00:08:04,790 --> 00:08:08,060
All right, unfortunately,
I've seen this before also.

159
00:08:08,060 --> 00:08:11,770
Normally, the first time you launch
Wireshark, it'll prompt you and say,

160
00:08:11,770 --> 00:08:13,570
hey, where's the X environment?

161
00:08:13,570 --> 00:08:17,200
And you browse, and you point it to X11,
and it's got it and it's happy.

162
00:08:17,200 --> 00:08:18,700
In my case, it didn't prompt.

163
00:08:18,700 --> 00:08:23,080
So, my next step is to launch XQuartz
first and then launch Wireshark.

164
00:08:23,080 --> 00:08:24,380
And it didn't prompt.

165
00:08:24,380 --> 00:08:27,950
My next thing is to close them both and
try and open Wireshark by itself.

166
00:08:27,950 --> 00:08:31,570
And if still doesn't work you might
actually have to reboot to take effect.

167
00:08:31,570 --> 00:08:34,100
I had a lot of this software installed
in my laptop prior to the show, and

168
00:08:34,100 --> 00:08:36,880
I uninstalled it, and
I haven't rebooted since then.

169
00:08:36,880 --> 00:08:40,150
So there's probably some old
preferences that are getting in my way.

170
00:08:40,150 --> 00:08:41,150
I've seen each of these.

171
00:08:41,150 --> 00:08:43,940
It's all little quirks with
getting Wireshark installed.

172
00:08:43,940 --> 00:08:45,775
Oh, actually,
looks like I just had to be patient.

173
00:08:45,775 --> 00:08:48,570
[LAUGH] If I waited long enough,
it launched.

174
00:08:48,570 --> 00:08:50,710
So anyhow,
that does give you guys an idea though,

175
00:08:50,710 --> 00:08:52,430
of some of the scenarios you might have.

176
00:08:52,430 --> 00:08:53,910
If you launched initially and

177
00:08:53,910 --> 00:08:57,940
it doesn't come up, it may be that it's
still just sorting out that environment.

178
00:08:57,940 --> 00:09:00,647
Now I'm in Wireshark,
I'm gonna get out of it though,

179
00:09:00,647 --> 00:09:03,364
because I wanna make sure you
guys see all this cleanly.

180
00:09:03,364 --> 00:09:08,160
Notice how I'm in WireShark but
in my menu bar up here, it say X11.

181
00:09:08,160 --> 00:09:10,135
The two are tied together.

182
00:09:10,135 --> 00:09:15,950
Wireshark is dependent on that X windows
environment, so it's connected in there.

183
00:09:15,950 --> 00:09:20,840
If we close the X environment, it'll close
every application that's tied into it.

184
00:09:20,840 --> 00:09:22,990
So I'm just gonna quit out entirely.

185
00:09:22,990 --> 00:09:27,630
So, at this point I don't have
Wireshark and I don't have X11 running.

186
00:09:27,630 --> 00:09:29,300
I don't have any of that stuff going on.

187
00:09:30,320 --> 00:09:32,660
And I'm just gonna run
Wireshark by itself.

188
00:09:32,660 --> 00:09:35,780
Now, I'm not launching X11 and
that's fine.

189
00:09:35,780 --> 00:09:37,360
Wireshark knows where to find it.

190
00:09:37,360 --> 00:09:38,510
And there it goes.

191
00:09:38,510 --> 00:09:41,491
So that first time you launch it,
it's a little bit tricky,

192
00:09:41,491 --> 00:09:43,710
but after that it runs nice and smooth.

193
00:09:43,710 --> 00:09:46,170
You don't even have to remember that
you've got XQuartz, you just go and

194
00:09:46,170 --> 00:09:49,028
run Wireshark and
it'll take care of launching it for you.

195
00:09:49,028 --> 00:09:53,625
So a little bit different than what we saw
under Windows where it was just able to

196
00:09:53,625 --> 00:09:56,910
use the Microsoft Windows Manager,
no big deal there.

197
00:09:56,910 --> 00:10:00,804
On the Linux side, you've already
got x.org, and so it uses that and

198
00:10:00,804 --> 00:10:02,063
it comes up just fine.

199
00:10:02,063 --> 00:10:06,703
But on Mac, because they didn't rewrite
the interface to be able to handle Aqua,

200
00:10:06,703 --> 00:10:10,550
they just went ahead and
basically brought over this port of X11.

201
00:10:10,550 --> 00:10:12,950
And that's what they use,
so a little bit tricky.

202
00:10:12,950 --> 00:10:16,055
Once you get past that, though,
it runs like any other application and

203
00:10:16,055 --> 00:10:16,950
you're good to go.

204
00:10:18,110 --> 00:10:20,600
All right, well,
hope you guys enjoyed that.

205
00:10:20,600 --> 00:10:21,100
Stayed tuned.

206
00:10:21,100 --> 00:10:23,570
We got more videos coming
up on how to use Wireshark,

207
00:10:23,570 --> 00:10:24,990
some of the other advanced features.

208
00:10:24,990 --> 00:10:26,320
Definitely be sure to check that out.

209
00:10:26,320 --> 00:10:29,600
But from this point it doesn't really
matter if you're on Mac, Windows or

210
00:10:29,600 --> 00:10:31,450
Linux, you're running Wireshark and

211
00:10:31,450 --> 00:10:34,265
it's the same on the three platforms
once you're past the install.

212
00:10:34,265 --> 00:10:40,034
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Capturing Packets
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,180 --> 00:00:08,381
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,381 --> 00:00:12,430
All right, now that we've got Wire Shark
installed, let's capture some data, right?

3
00:00:12,430 --> 00:00:15,040
That's how we make this thing
useful is get data into it.

4
00:00:15,040 --> 00:00:18,320
So, I'm going to fire up Wire Shark
here and we'll get started.

5
00:00:18,320 --> 00:00:21,270
Now, when you launch Wire Shark up,
it's gonna fire up.

6
00:00:21,270 --> 00:00:23,510
And it's basically going to
present you with this screen.

7
00:00:23,510 --> 00:00:28,320
And it's asking you whether you're wanting
to capture new data or open existing data.

8
00:00:28,320 --> 00:00:30,410
You might have data you
captured previously or

9
00:00:30,410 --> 00:00:33,430
that you captured with the text
utility from the command line.

10
00:00:33,430 --> 00:00:36,480
And now you wanna go and open it up and
take a look at some data.

11
00:00:36,480 --> 00:00:38,830
It's actually got some sample
captures you can look at,

12
00:00:38,830 --> 00:00:41,660
just to get an idea of
how the software works.

13
00:00:41,660 --> 00:00:44,760
What I wanna do is I wanna
capture some live data.

14
00:00:44,760 --> 00:00:48,460
It's got a list of my interfaces
right here that I can pick from, but

15
00:00:48,460 --> 00:00:49,650
I'm really bad about this.

16
00:00:49,650 --> 00:00:52,940
I've always got multiple multiple
network adapters in my system, and

17
00:00:52,940 --> 00:00:55,340
I can never remember
which one is plugged in.

18
00:00:55,340 --> 00:00:58,350
Sometimes, I've bothered to rename them so
I know what they are,

19
00:00:58,350 --> 00:01:00,029
like this is my Genus Three network.

20
00:01:00,029 --> 00:01:03,650
Sometimes I haven't, though, and I've got
things like Local Area Connection Eight.

21
00:01:03,650 --> 00:01:05,928
So, one of the things
that I like to do is,

22
00:01:05,928 --> 00:01:10,630
instead of using this set of options here,
I like to go up to the Interface List.

23
00:01:10,630 --> 00:01:14,190
When you click on the Interface List,
you can see all your interfaces, and

24
00:01:14,190 --> 00:01:16,100
you can see which ones
are receiving traffic.

25
00:01:16,100 --> 00:01:19,960
That let's me spot really quick which
one it is that's actually plugged in and

26
00:01:19,960 --> 00:01:20,860
in use.

27
00:01:20,860 --> 00:01:24,090
And I can see the you
know IPv6 address that's

28
00:01:24,090 --> 00:01:25,660
attached to an interface or whatever.

29
00:01:25,660 --> 00:01:29,240
So, the easy way to kinda go in and
spot which adapter you want.

30
00:01:29,240 --> 00:01:33,410
You can capture from more than
one adapter at the same time.

31
00:01:33,410 --> 00:01:36,580
I don't recommend it, because it's
a kind of a lot for the system to do.

32
00:01:36,580 --> 00:01:38,930
But you can capture multiple NICs at once.

33
00:01:38,930 --> 00:01:42,340
So, you'll see where I can come over
here and check off a couple of these and

34
00:01:42,340 --> 00:01:43,640
now I'm doing a capture.

35
00:01:43,640 --> 00:01:46,020
This is the same as if I
had done it from out here.

36
00:01:46,020 --> 00:01:48,580
See how we can just
highlight multiple entries?

37
00:01:48,580 --> 00:01:50,930
And we can go in and
capture these different entries.

38
00:01:50,930 --> 00:01:52,210
That's the same thing.

39
00:01:52,210 --> 00:01:54,830
No real difference between the two.

40
00:01:54,830 --> 00:01:59,095
In fact, the interface list is really
just combining these two sets of options

41
00:01:59,095 --> 00:01:59,990
right here.

42
00:01:59,990 --> 00:02:03,640
The option to pick pick which
interface and my capture options.

43
00:02:03,640 --> 00:02:06,120
Let's take a look at those capture
options before we get started,

44
00:02:06,120 --> 00:02:08,010
cuz they're kind of important.

45
00:02:08,010 --> 00:02:11,400
Basically, it's got a few entries
in here that are useful for us.

46
00:02:11,400 --> 00:02:13,570
You don't have to change any
of these if you don't want to.

47
00:02:13,570 --> 00:02:17,500
If you just want to capture packets and
have them on the screen and look at it and

48
00:02:17,500 --> 00:02:21,150
manually start and stop the capture, then
you don't need to change these at all.

49
00:02:21,150 --> 00:02:22,820
That's exactly how it works.

50
00:02:22,820 --> 00:02:25,810
You start a capture,
it dumps it to your screen and

51
00:02:25,810 --> 00:02:28,690
it keeps doing that until
you tell it to stop.

52
00:02:28,690 --> 00:02:32,080
And if you just let it run and run and
run, you'll either run out of RAM or

53
00:02:32,080 --> 00:02:34,950
run out of hard drive space and
then it'll stop.

54
00:02:34,950 --> 00:02:37,550
So one way or another,
it'll stop eventually.

55
00:02:37,550 --> 00:02:40,220
But we can control a lot of that,
right here.

56
00:02:40,220 --> 00:02:43,240
You'll see where we can pick which
interface we're gonna capture on.

57
00:02:43,240 --> 00:02:46,160
We can specify a capture filter.

58
00:02:46,160 --> 00:02:49,330
There might be some traffic that's
coming in that we just don't care about.

59
00:02:49,330 --> 00:02:51,680
And I don't need that filling up
my hard drive space or whatever,

60
00:02:51,680 --> 00:02:54,000
if it's something that I
wanna filter out anyway.

61
00:02:54,000 --> 00:02:56,970
A lot of times, I'll put a filter on
there to filter my own workstation out.

62
00:02:56,970 --> 00:02:58,420
I don't want to see my own traffic.

63
00:02:58,420 --> 00:02:59,620
That's not why I'm watching the network.

64
00:02:59,620 --> 00:03:01,800
I want to see other traffic.

65
00:03:01,800 --> 00:03:04,575
We'll do a separate video on
the filters a little bit later,

66
00:03:04,575 --> 00:03:07,460
cuz there's a particular
filter syntax that we'll see.

67
00:03:08,580 --> 00:03:10,940
More importantly though,
we've got our capture files.

68
00:03:10,940 --> 00:03:15,490
So, I can say I'm gonna do a capture and
this is the file that I want to log to.

69
00:03:15,490 --> 00:03:19,120
So, I can come in here and
I can specify a particular file.

70
00:03:19,120 --> 00:03:26,620
I'll just call this Show Capture, and
I'll save that right here on my desktop.

71
00:03:26,620 --> 00:03:27,144
There we go.
So

72
00:03:27,144 --> 00:03:29,943
now I'm gonna be saving to
this Show Capture folder.

73
00:03:29,943 --> 00:03:32,624
And I can tell it whether I
want it to be one file or

74
00:03:32,624 --> 00:03:35,090
if I wanna do multiple files, right?

75
00:03:35,090 --> 00:03:38,055
Multiple files are nice if you're worried
about having files larger than what your

76
00:03:38,055 --> 00:03:39,550
file system can support.

77
00:03:39,550 --> 00:03:43,210
Maybe you're on FAT32 and you can't
have a file over four gigs in size.

78
00:03:43,210 --> 00:03:46,150
Maybe you just want smaller files so
that it's easier to analyze.

79
00:03:46,150 --> 00:03:49,900
The larger files take longer to analyze,
so you might wanna break it up.

80
00:03:49,900 --> 00:03:54,940
And so you can break it up by size or
by time, right?

81
00:03:54,940 --> 00:03:59,020
I might wanna say, create a separate
log file every 30 minutes.

82
00:03:59,020 --> 00:04:04,350
So, if I run this scan for six hours,
it'll create 12 files, alright?

83
00:04:04,350 --> 00:04:06,108
Or, you might wanna go by size.

84
00:04:06,108 --> 00:04:10,400
Just every time it hits 200 megabytes,
go ahead and break it into a new file.

85
00:04:10,400 --> 00:04:14,040
Whatever works for you,
you can choose right there.

86
00:04:14,040 --> 00:04:16,320
And then you also have what
is called a ring buffer.

87
00:04:16,320 --> 00:04:17,390
Now, what is that?

88
00:04:17,390 --> 00:04:18,670
What is ring buffering?

89
00:04:18,670 --> 00:04:23,310
Well that means you limit the amount
of data that you can write, and

90
00:04:23,310 --> 00:04:28,150
when you fill it up, you just go back and
start overwriting the older stuff.

91
00:04:28,150 --> 00:04:33,280
So if I say,
create a new file every one hour.

92
00:04:33,280 --> 00:04:36,320
Okay, so every hour I want
it to create a new file, and

93
00:04:36,320 --> 00:04:39,680
I set the ring buffer to six, okay?

94
00:04:39,680 --> 00:04:43,760
That means each hour for six hours,
it's gonna create a file.

95
00:04:43,760 --> 00:04:48,360
But on the seventh hour, it'll delete
the first file and overwrite it.

96
00:04:48,360 --> 00:04:54,280
So, I'll never have more than six files
because I chose one file an hour and

97
00:04:54,280 --> 00:04:55,200
ring buffer at six.

98
00:04:55,200 --> 00:04:56,710
So, I'll never have more than six files.

99
00:04:56,710 --> 00:04:58,560
It works the same way for size.

100
00:04:58,560 --> 00:05:03,060
If I said every one gigabyte, and

101
00:05:03,060 --> 00:05:07,830
a ring buffer with six files,
that means I'll have six gigs of files.

102
00:05:07,830 --> 00:05:10,470
And when it fills that up,
it'll just overwrite the original one.

103
00:05:10,470 --> 00:05:15,150
So, some people call this log rotation or
rotating.

104
00:05:15,150 --> 00:05:16,590
There's different names for it.

105
00:05:16,590 --> 00:05:19,330
But basically,
we're doing circular logging.

106
00:05:19,330 --> 00:05:22,020
At the end,
it starts to overwrite the beginning.

107
00:05:22,020 --> 00:05:27,276
I'm gonna turn those off though, cuz I'm
gonna do manual execution All right,

108
00:05:27,276 --> 00:05:31,850
then we've got stop capture
automatically after.

109
00:05:31,850 --> 00:05:34,990
By default, when you start a capture,
it'll run forever.

110
00:05:34,990 --> 00:05:36,830
It'll run until you stop it.

111
00:05:36,830 --> 00:05:39,560
But if you just want to run it for
the day, and capture some data,

112
00:05:39,560 --> 00:05:41,770
you might wanna stop it
at a particular time.

113
00:05:41,770 --> 00:05:45,170
So you can come in and you can say,
stop after a certain amount of packets or

114
00:05:45,170 --> 00:05:46,960
stop after a certain amount of files.

115
00:05:46,960 --> 00:05:48,000
You'll have those options.

116
00:05:48,000 --> 00:05:49,620
And see how some of these are grayed out?

117
00:05:49,620 --> 00:05:52,630
It's because it's influenced by
the options up above, right, whether or

118
00:05:52,630 --> 00:05:53,800
not you'll see these.

119
00:05:53,800 --> 00:05:55,380
So there's particular mixes and

120
00:05:55,380 --> 00:05:57,749
matches that you have to do to
get all the different options.

121
00:05:59,680 --> 00:06:02,620
Other things we've got,
display options, right?

122
00:06:02,620 --> 00:06:05,940
This one right here: update
list of packets in real time.

123
00:06:05,940 --> 00:06:09,150
If you're gonna be watching
this on the screen,

124
00:06:09,150 --> 00:06:11,340
it'll display the packets in real time.

125
00:06:11,340 --> 00:06:12,960
That takes a lot of CPU power.

126
00:06:12,960 --> 00:06:16,180
It takes a lot of resources to do that,
especially on a busy network.

127
00:06:16,180 --> 00:06:20,610
So you can turn that off and say don't
update the list of packets in real time.

128
00:06:20,610 --> 00:06:23,770
If you're just gonna analyze this later,
you're not going to analyze it now,

129
00:06:23,770 --> 00:06:26,670
you're gonna analyze it later,
don't display it on the screen.

130
00:06:26,670 --> 00:06:29,340
It'll speed up performance considerably.

131
00:06:29,340 --> 00:06:31,740
Now it just gets the packets and
writes them to the hard drive.

132
00:06:31,740 --> 00:06:35,420
As opposed to getting the packets and
having to write them to the screen and

133
00:06:35,420 --> 00:06:37,570
do real time interpretation.

134
00:06:37,570 --> 00:06:40,740
Now, on a fast machine,
it's not that big of an impact.

135
00:06:40,740 --> 00:06:42,470
But if this is an older machine or

136
00:06:42,470 --> 00:06:45,760
a machine where you're gonna be doing
other work on it at the same time,

137
00:06:45,760 --> 00:06:50,060
it's a good idea to turn off that
real time display, all right?

138
00:06:50,060 --> 00:06:52,740
Other things, like automatically
scroll during live capture.

139
00:06:52,740 --> 00:06:55,770
So, it's keeping the newest packets
on the screen at all times.

140
00:06:55,770 --> 00:06:57,990
Again that takes up some resources.

141
00:06:57,990 --> 00:07:00,030
Hide capture info dialog.

142
00:07:00,030 --> 00:07:01,415
When you float over or

143
00:07:01,415 --> 00:07:04,690
double-click on a capture item it'll
display some information on it.

144
00:07:04,690 --> 00:07:05,720
You can choose to hide that,

145
00:07:05,720 --> 00:07:08,820
which again will help to improve
performance of the capture.

146
00:07:08,820 --> 00:07:11,320
And notice,
if I turn off update list in real time,

147
00:07:11,320 --> 00:07:12,930
automatically scrolling is turned off.

148
00:07:12,930 --> 00:07:15,110
So, some of these are tied together.

149
00:07:15,110 --> 00:07:17,800
And then down here, name resolution.

150
00:07:17,800 --> 00:07:19,980
This is another one that
affects performance.

151
00:07:19,980 --> 00:07:24,460
When it gets a MAC address or
when it gets an IP address, it can try and

152
00:07:24,460 --> 00:07:26,080
resolve that to a name.

153
00:07:26,080 --> 00:07:28,980
That's helpful for us if we're trying to
keep track of what machine is what and

154
00:07:28,980 --> 00:07:30,482
we don't have all our IPs memorized.

155
00:07:31,500 --> 00:07:34,000
But, It does create some effort.

156
00:07:34,000 --> 00:07:35,860
So, you've got resolve MAC addresses.

157
00:07:35,860 --> 00:07:38,200
That one is checked by default cuz
that's an easy one to look up.

158
00:07:38,200 --> 00:07:42,690
You know, a MAC address is 48 bits,
and the first 24 bits identify

159
00:07:42,690 --> 00:07:46,118
the manufacturer and
the last 24 bits are random stuff.

160
00:07:46,118 --> 00:07:48,040
So here it'll look a the first 24 bits and
it'll say,

161
00:07:48,040 --> 00:07:52,270
oh that's a Dell network card or
HP or Cisco, Juniper, whatever.

162
00:07:52,270 --> 00:07:54,050
And it'll show who that vendor is.

163
00:07:54,050 --> 00:07:54,879
That's on by default.

164
00:07:55,890 --> 00:07:58,590
But network layer names, right.

165
00:07:58,590 --> 00:08:00,095
That's your IP addresses.

166
00:08:00,095 --> 00:08:04,400
It'll take your IPs and do a reverse DNS
look up to try and find the host name.

167
00:08:04,400 --> 00:08:06,580
That takes a little bit more effort.

168
00:08:06,580 --> 00:08:09,950
Because we gotta do a lookup for
each one individually versus a vendor,

169
00:08:09,950 --> 00:08:12,828
where it's almost common
throughout your data.

170
00:08:12,828 --> 00:08:15,850
Here's it's different.
So that one's turned off by default.

171
00:08:15,850 --> 00:08:18,060
Resolve transport layer names.

172
00:08:18,060 --> 00:08:20,120
Now, we're up at that TCP layer.

173
00:08:20,120 --> 00:08:22,980
That's where it's gonna take a look at the
ports that are communicating and try and

174
00:08:22,980 --> 00:08:25,020
turn those into names.

175
00:08:25,020 --> 00:08:28,030
And then lastly,
use external network name resolver.

176
00:08:28,030 --> 00:08:31,890
That's where, do we do the look
ups just on our own local cache?

177
00:08:31,890 --> 00:08:36,110
Or do we actually reach out to things
like a DNS server to look for that?

178
00:08:36,110 --> 00:08:39,610
This is all good stuff, cuz it makes
the information easier to interpret, but

179
00:08:39,610 --> 00:08:40,970
it does affect performance.

180
00:08:40,970 --> 00:08:43,100
So, I may or may not wanna turn these on,

181
00:08:43,100 --> 00:08:45,420
depending on whether I'm gonna use my
system while it's scanning or not.

182
00:08:46,960 --> 00:08:47,720
All right, so

183
00:08:47,720 --> 00:08:52,220
those are all some of the options that
we can choose when we turn on a scan.

184
00:08:52,220 --> 00:08:53,740
I'm gonna cancel out of that,

185
00:08:53,740 --> 00:08:56,870
because I'm gonna just run with
the default options and fire it up.

186
00:08:58,010 --> 00:09:00,070
Basically, if you want to do a quick and
easy scan,

187
00:09:00,070 --> 00:09:03,480
you just choose the adaptor you wanna
scan, and you hit the Start button.

188
00:09:03,480 --> 00:09:06,140
Or, like I said, what I normally
do is go to the interface list,

189
00:09:06,140 --> 00:09:08,650
cuz I can never remember
which adapter is live.

190
00:09:08,650 --> 00:09:13,130
I find the adapter I want, and
I choose it, and hit Start, all right?

191
00:09:13,130 --> 00:09:17,120
So, whichever way you choose to go about
it, there's different ways to find it.

192
00:09:17,120 --> 00:09:19,440
Set up your options, and
fire up that capture.

193
00:09:19,440 --> 00:09:22,580
Now, since I've gone in here, and
changed some of my capture options,

194
00:09:22,580 --> 00:09:25,590
it's got a few different things
clicked and changed now.

195
00:09:25,590 --> 00:09:29,670
Actually I think I've put everything
back to the way that it was.

196
00:09:30,830 --> 00:09:32,820
Let me just scan that real quick,
make sure it's all good.

197
00:09:32,820 --> 00:09:34,270
I believe it is.

198
00:09:34,270 --> 00:09:38,780
So, if I fire that up,
it's gonna start capturing and

199
00:09:38,780 --> 00:09:42,120
right off I can start to
see data flowing through.

200
00:09:42,120 --> 00:09:46,060
Now, there's a lot of information
passing through when it connects, and

201
00:09:46,060 --> 00:09:47,980
sometimes it might not look
like its updating at all.

202
00:09:47,980 --> 00:09:49,830
It may look like its standing still.

203
00:09:49,830 --> 00:09:53,290
So, you can look down here at the bottom
to get an idea of whether anything's

204
00:09:53,290 --> 00:09:54,530
actually happening.

205
00:09:54,530 --> 00:09:59,350
And I can see in the few moments that I've
run, it's captured over 180,000 packets.

206
00:10:00,360 --> 00:10:03,140
And it's displayed, well now over 200,000.

207
00:10:03,140 --> 00:10:07,370
That mean's I'm in a 100% real
time display mode right now.

208
00:10:07,370 --> 00:10:09,260
I'm seeing everything that comes through.

209
00:10:09,260 --> 00:10:12,190
It's possible that my
display could get behind and

210
00:10:12,190 --> 00:10:15,280
I might see where I've received more
packets than are being displayed.

211
00:10:15,280 --> 00:10:16,189
That can happen.

212
00:10:16,189 --> 00:10:17,510
But it's capturing and it's running.

213
00:10:17,510 --> 00:10:20,650
I'm over 300,000 packets now,
and it's churning along.

214
00:10:21,980 --> 00:10:26,050
The interface is broken up into a couple
of different pieces, which I'll describe.

215
00:10:26,050 --> 00:10:28,140
Actually I'll do that in
a separate video segment.

216
00:10:28,140 --> 00:10:29,800
So we'll see that in
the next video segment.

217
00:10:29,800 --> 00:10:32,340
But the main part here that I'm
concerned about is this little

218
00:10:32,340 --> 00:10:33,770
status bar right here at the bottom.

219
00:10:33,770 --> 00:10:36,900
It's letting me know I am capturing data,

220
00:10:36,900 --> 00:10:38,890
I'm gathering the information and
it's right there.

221
00:10:40,030 --> 00:10:42,440
All right, so
that's how we start capturing data.

222
00:10:42,440 --> 00:10:42,940
Stay tuned.

223
00:10:42,940 --> 00:10:46,020
In our next video we're gonna
see how this interface works.

224
00:10:46,020 --> 00:10:48,130
We'll kind of walk through
the user interface and

225
00:10:48,130 --> 00:10:49,820
then we'll start to work
with some of the data too.

226
00:10:49,820 --> 00:10:51,790
So I hope to see you then.

227
00:10:51,790 --> 00:10:57,979
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: User Interface
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:05,286
[SOUND] So
one of the most intimidating things about

2
00:00:05,286 --> 00:00:11,048
Wireshark can be how much
data it's throwing at you and

3
00:00:11,048 --> 00:00:16,948
the user interface and
it's just a lot to kind of grasp.

4
00:00:16,948 --> 00:00:19,974
So, in this video, I want to take
a look at that user interface and

5
00:00:19,974 --> 00:00:23,661
just kind of show you what's going on and
what we expect to see in the software and

6
00:00:23,661 --> 00:00:24,725
help make sense of it.

7
00:00:24,725 --> 00:00:26,276
In an earlier episode,

8
00:00:26,276 --> 00:00:31,120
we covered all of the basic stuff of
getting a packet capture started.

9
00:00:31,120 --> 00:00:35,190
So, I'm just going to fire one up here and
get that running.

10
00:00:35,190 --> 00:00:38,163
So, this is the interface that
we're going to see the majority

11
00:00:38,163 --> 00:00:40,700
of the time that we're
working inside of Wireshark.

12
00:00:40,700 --> 00:00:43,938
Like most Windows software,
or really software on any OS,

13
00:00:43,938 --> 00:00:48,018
you've got your task bar at the top
where you've got various menu items and

14
00:00:48,018 --> 00:00:51,023
icons that represent stuff
that's in the menu items.

15
00:00:51,023 --> 00:00:52,634
A little bit of redundancy, and

16
00:00:52,634 --> 00:00:55,460
then you've got a status
bar here at the bottom.

17
00:00:55,460 --> 00:00:59,290
Now the status bar is pretty handy
because it's letting me know that I'm

18
00:00:59,290 --> 00:01:01,110
actually capturing data.

19
00:01:01,110 --> 00:01:03,900
So we see that this stuff is
being updated in real time,

20
00:01:03,900 --> 00:01:05,690
we can see what's kind of happening.

21
00:01:06,960 --> 00:01:09,060
But let's take a look at
each of these pieces.

22
00:01:09,060 --> 00:01:11,197
Up at the top I've got my menu bar and

23
00:01:11,197 --> 00:01:15,342
just like any software I've got
things like file and save or save as.

24
00:01:15,342 --> 00:01:18,711
Notice that my save and save as options
are kind of grayed out right now,

25
00:01:18,711 --> 00:01:20,972
and that's because I'm actively capturing.

26
00:01:20,972 --> 00:01:25,264
Some of these options will light up
only when you're not capturing so

27
00:01:25,264 --> 00:01:29,800
I might have to stop or pause
the capture to be able to save the file.

28
00:01:29,800 --> 00:01:33,080
It can't say if a file was being actively
written to is its main problem there.

29
00:01:33,080 --> 00:01:37,118
You'll see where I can export packets and
do some really cool things.

30
00:01:37,118 --> 00:01:39,046
Under Edit we've got our Copy, Paste,

31
00:01:39,046 --> 00:01:42,730
all the different things that we'd
expect to have inside of software.

32
00:01:42,730 --> 00:01:45,333
We're gonna use some of these
options in later episodes.

33
00:01:45,333 --> 00:01:46,819
Things like Time Shift is really cool.

34
00:01:46,819 --> 00:01:49,370
So we'll get a chance to see those.

35
00:01:49,370 --> 00:01:50,470
But for the most part,

36
00:01:50,470 --> 00:01:54,330
what's up here is really is really being
represented is these icons down here.

37
00:01:54,330 --> 00:01:56,410
These are the most common menu items.

38
00:01:56,410 --> 00:01:59,220
And so they're the ones we are going
to use on a regular basis.

39
00:01:59,220 --> 00:02:01,640
And if you look at them they're
pretty straight forward.

40
00:02:01,640 --> 00:02:05,550
These three guys right here, the green
shark fin, that's starting the capture and

41
00:02:05,550 --> 00:02:08,430
that's grayed out for
me cuz I'm already in a capture.

42
00:02:08,430 --> 00:02:11,990
But I can also stop the capture or
restart the capture.

43
00:02:11,990 --> 00:02:14,632
Stopping it, that just stops
me from gathering stuff and

44
00:02:14,632 --> 00:02:16,401
frees the system up to be able to work.

45
00:02:16,401 --> 00:02:20,360
I can see my packet numbers down
here have stopped incrementing.

46
00:02:20,360 --> 00:02:23,000
So now I'm not recording anymore.

47
00:02:23,000 --> 00:02:26,460
It's just sitting here waiting for
me to do something, all right?

48
00:02:26,460 --> 00:02:29,091
And that restart button
if I would have hit that,

49
00:02:29,091 --> 00:02:32,183
would have wiped out the capture and
started over again.

50
00:02:32,183 --> 00:02:37,140
And started capturing again with
our new data coming in, all right?

51
00:02:37,140 --> 00:02:40,480
My green fin lit up again, so
I can start a new capture.

52
00:02:40,480 --> 00:02:44,690
On the initial page when I first
launched Wireshark, I had options to

53
00:02:44,690 --> 00:02:48,990
pick my interface, and I had options
to change the capture options, right?

54
00:02:48,990 --> 00:02:49,970
What if we're already beyond that.

55
00:02:49,970 --> 00:02:51,980
Well that's what these
first two icons are.

56
00:02:51,980 --> 00:02:54,790
The first icon pulls up
that interface list.

57
00:02:54,790 --> 00:02:57,640
So I can pick which interface
I'm capturing on and

58
00:02:57,640 --> 00:02:59,690
I can change it from here.

59
00:02:59,690 --> 00:03:03,830
The second icon is the capture options and
if I click on that there's my capture

60
00:03:03,830 --> 00:03:08,270
options and so I can adjust things like
what file it's writing to and all of that.

61
00:03:08,270 --> 00:03:11,120
I think I did that in a different episode.

62
00:03:13,300 --> 00:03:16,871
So I can come in here and
punch in that information.

63
00:03:16,871 --> 00:03:19,715
And so now, it's got it and
off we go, right..

64
00:03:19,715 --> 00:03:22,330
So we can start that
capture back up again.

65
00:03:22,330 --> 00:03:23,650
If I try and start a new capture,

66
00:03:23,650 --> 00:03:25,200
it's going to ask what I
want to do with the old one.

67
00:03:25,200 --> 00:03:27,710
Do I want to save it or
do I want to just throw it out.

68
00:03:27,710 --> 00:03:29,260
I'm going to say continue without saving.

69
00:03:29,260 --> 00:03:31,000
That means throw out my old capture and
start again.

70
00:03:31,000 --> 00:03:32,764
So there it goes trying to close it.

71
00:03:32,764 --> 00:03:36,450
Apparently it's taking its time.

72
00:03:36,450 --> 00:03:37,740
And then once it's closed,
it will start again.

73
00:03:37,740 --> 00:03:40,815
And it's actually returned me back
to this little wizard screen.

74
00:03:40,815 --> 00:03:44,926
But I didn't have to come to this because
I had the menu options up here to do it.

75
00:03:44,926 --> 00:03:51,760
So, if you see a long closing time like
this, it usually means one of two things.

76
00:03:51,760 --> 00:03:54,810
One, it may mean you
just have an incredibly,

77
00:03:54,810 --> 00:03:56,530
I got a little click happy there.

78
00:03:56,530 --> 00:03:58,310
It probably means you have
an incredibly large capture file.

79
00:03:58,310 --> 00:04:02,303
You've captured a lot of data to RAM and
it's having to write it to hard drive, or

80
00:04:02,303 --> 00:04:04,021
two it could be file permissions.

81
00:04:04,021 --> 00:04:07,117
Mine finished, so that just means
I captured a lot of data, so

82
00:04:07,117 --> 00:04:08,618
it took it a while to write it.

83
00:04:08,618 --> 00:04:12,831
But if I had, you know, still been sitting
here and it wasn't done, it could mean

84
00:04:12,831 --> 00:04:16,640
that it was trying to write to a file
that it doesn't have permissions to.

85
00:04:16,640 --> 00:04:19,190
So that could be another reason
that it's sitting there.

86
00:04:19,190 --> 00:04:22,230
But mine finally finished and
now it's started a new capture and

87
00:04:22,230 --> 00:04:23,310
it's churning along.

88
00:04:23,310 --> 00:04:25,400
I was over 800,000 packets before, and

89
00:04:25,400 --> 00:04:28,889
