now I see that I'm just creeping up on
300,000, so I know it did start over.

90
00:04:30,080 --> 00:04:31,970
All right.
Let me stop that so

91
00:04:31,970 --> 00:04:33,730
it doesn't go crazy on me.

92
00:04:33,730 --> 00:04:35,190
All right.
The rest of these options,

93
00:04:35,190 --> 00:04:38,270
we're gonna tackle later on
in other segments cuz there's

94
00:04:38,270 --> 00:04:41,870
a lot of stuff in here as far
as reloading captures and so on.

95
00:04:41,870 --> 00:04:44,853
The rest of the interface is really
made of of three primary panes,

96
00:04:44,853 --> 00:04:45,770
like window panes.

97
00:04:45,770 --> 00:04:48,446
The top part here,
this is my live packet capture, so

98
00:04:48,446 --> 00:04:51,364
it's listing all of the packets
that have been captured.

99
00:04:51,364 --> 00:04:52,805
Well, it was live when I was running it.

100
00:04:52,805 --> 00:04:55,040
Now that I've stopped it,
it's kind of frozen.

101
00:04:55,040 --> 00:04:57,990
But I can see all the different
packets that came through.

102
00:04:57,990 --> 00:05:02,090
And it breaks them down based on
the time we captured it, the source IP,

103
00:05:02,090 --> 00:05:03,360
the destination IP,

104
00:05:03,360 --> 00:05:07,910
the protocol that was used, and
that's the transport layer protocol.

105
00:05:07,910 --> 00:05:09,370
The length of the packet.

106
00:05:09,370 --> 00:05:14,040
I'm seeing all of that information right
there that it gathered off of that.

107
00:05:14,040 --> 00:05:19,020
As I click on each packet,
the bottom two frames will update.

108
00:05:19,020 --> 00:05:22,800
The middle one,
this is the packet that's been dissected.

109
00:05:22,800 --> 00:05:27,300
It's broken it apart and turned it
into something that's human readable.

110
00:05:27,300 --> 00:05:28,250
A packet,

111
00:05:28,250 --> 00:05:30,950
you know really what we're gathering
are frames at the end of the day.

112
00:05:30,950 --> 00:05:34,210
And a frame is made up of
several layers of data.

113
00:05:34,210 --> 00:05:36,630
This is all from the OSI model, right.

114
00:05:36,630 --> 00:05:39,970
We have our seven layer
networking OSI model, and

115
00:05:39,970 --> 00:05:43,082
each layer represents a certain
amount of information.

116
00:05:43,082 --> 00:05:47,140
Well, Wireshark is taking
each of these packets, and

117
00:05:47,140 --> 00:05:51,080
breaking down those layers of
the OSI model to show us that data.

118
00:05:51,080 --> 00:05:54,110
So I can come in here and
I can see the frame information.

119
00:05:54,110 --> 00:05:57,160
Frame, right,
that's layer two of the OSI model.

120
00:05:57,160 --> 00:05:59,890
And so I can look in and
I can see information about

121
00:05:59,890 --> 00:06:03,380
things like the source MAC address,
the destination MAC address.

122
00:06:03,380 --> 00:06:06,570
I can see the, there's the source and
destination MAC address.

123
00:06:06,570 --> 00:06:10,440
I can see the CRC,
the check sum that was done.

124
00:06:10,440 --> 00:06:11,290
The header lengths.

125
00:06:11,290 --> 00:06:16,870
All that stuff is stored right here in
the layer two information of that frame.

126
00:06:19,190 --> 00:06:24,550
Then we see the layer three and
layer four sections from the OSI model.

127
00:06:24,550 --> 00:06:26,490
Layer three for me is Internet protocol.

128
00:06:26,490 --> 00:06:29,610
I'm using TC/IP,
IP is layer three protocol.

129
00:06:29,610 --> 00:06:32,918
So I can see things like the source and
destination IP address.

130
00:06:32,918 --> 00:06:37,000
They're right down here,
source and destination IPs.

131
00:06:37,000 --> 00:06:37,990
All right.

132
00:06:37,990 --> 00:06:41,020
And then I can see layer four for
whatever this packet was.

133
00:06:41,020 --> 00:06:41,850
So I clicked on this one.

134
00:06:41,850 --> 00:06:43,680
This was a TCP packet.

135
00:06:43,680 --> 00:06:48,845
And if I expand it out here it will
show the source port was 49,200,

136
00:06:48,845 --> 00:06:51,733
my destination port was 49,490.

137
00:06:51,733 --> 00:06:52,464
All right?

138
00:06:52,464 --> 00:06:53,440
What protocol is that?

139
00:06:53,440 --> 00:06:55,500
I have no idea, right?

140
00:06:55,500 --> 00:06:59,610
Protocols with a port
number that's over 1,024,

141
00:06:59,610 --> 00:07:01,650
we don't necessarily know
exactly what they are.

142
00:07:01,650 --> 00:07:02,560
Some of them are registered.

143
00:07:02,560 --> 00:07:04,310
There's a lot of registered
ports higher than that.

144
00:07:04,310 --> 00:07:08,970
But when they're this high, 49,000,
that's in that range where it's free use.

145
00:07:08,970 --> 00:07:10,470
So any software can use this.

146
00:07:10,470 --> 00:07:13,270
So I don't really know what
this communication is just

147
00:07:13,270 --> 00:07:14,890
based on a port number.

148
00:07:14,890 --> 00:07:18,270
But sometimes we'll get packets that
are a little more recognizable.

149
00:07:18,270 --> 00:07:20,700
Let me see if I can find one.

150
00:07:20,700 --> 00:07:21,590
Well, there's DHCP.

151
00:07:21,590 --> 00:07:24,940
DHCP's a bad example though,
because it's broadcast.

152
00:07:24,940 --> 00:07:26,520
But I guess it'll do in a pinch.

153
00:07:27,630 --> 00:07:30,815
All right, so
here's a DHCP packet that's going out.

154
00:07:30,815 --> 00:07:34,225
And so when I look in here, I'll see the
layer one, layer two, layer three stuff.

155
00:07:34,225 --> 00:07:37,105
You don't see layer one,
right, that's physical.

156
00:07:37,105 --> 00:07:40,865
But there's no layer four side to DHCP,
it's just a broadcast out.

157
00:07:40,865 --> 00:07:45,595
So this is actually DHCP V6, which is
actually a multicast out that's going on.

158
00:07:45,595 --> 00:07:48,685
So I can start to see some of
that information and dissect it.

159
00:07:48,685 --> 00:07:51,720
But the point is the top
pane is the list of packets.

160
00:07:51,720 --> 00:07:56,362
The middle pane is a human
readable breakdown of that packet.

161
00:07:56,362 --> 00:08:02,190
And then the third pane, the one at
the bottom, that's the raw packet itself.

162
00:08:02,190 --> 00:08:07,230
This was what was actually being sent
across the network for that particular

163
00:08:07,230 --> 00:08:11,320
communication, so we start to look at
some of these, that's the raw data.

164
00:08:11,320 --> 00:08:14,020
Well, these packets here that
I don't know what they are.

165
00:08:14,020 --> 00:08:15,900
Well, I actually do know what they are.

166
00:08:15,900 --> 00:08:18,030
That's my IP address on the left, and

167
00:08:18,030 --> 00:08:20,620
the IP address on the right is
the IP of our video switch.

168
00:08:20,620 --> 00:08:21,750
That's my shared desktop.

169
00:08:21,750 --> 00:08:25,170
I'm sharing my screen using some
video sharing software and that's it.

170
00:08:25,170 --> 00:08:28,430
Now when I look at this down here,
I just see a bunch of hexadecimal and

171
00:08:28,430 --> 00:08:29,640
machine code garbage.

172
00:08:29,640 --> 00:08:31,190
Doesn't mean anything to me.

173
00:08:31,190 --> 00:08:33,999
But, that's actually the encoded
video of my desktop.

174
00:08:33,999 --> 00:08:37,040
That's a picture of my desktop, right?

175
00:08:37,040 --> 00:08:38,530
It may actually be a couple pictures,

176
00:08:38,530 --> 00:08:40,510
depending on how much fit
inside of that packet.

177
00:08:40,510 --> 00:08:44,900
But it's probably just one snapshot
of my desktop right there.

178
00:08:44,900 --> 00:08:47,300
And it doesn't make any sense down here.

179
00:08:47,300 --> 00:08:50,750
But when it interprets it, when it
breaks it down in this middle pane,

180
00:08:52,080 --> 00:08:54,450
we can start to see a lot
more information about it.

181
00:08:54,450 --> 00:08:56,860
The ports, the source, the destination.

182
00:08:56,860 --> 00:08:58,340
It's probably a part of a sequence, right?

183
00:08:58,340 --> 00:09:01,947
There's probably more than one frame or
packet being sent for this so

184
00:09:01,947 --> 00:09:04,005
it can actually string that together.

185
00:09:04,005 --> 00:09:08,270
Here's my sequence number, 11,681.

186
00:09:08,270 --> 00:09:12,252
That means there's probably an 11,680 and
probably an 11,682, and

187
00:09:12,252 --> 00:09:16,010
Wireshark can actually string those
together to show me the whole sequence.

188
00:09:16,010 --> 00:09:17,660
It's really cool stuff.

189
00:09:17,660 --> 00:09:22,640
All right, the last part of
the user interface is right

190
00:09:22,640 --> 00:09:25,370
here at the bottom which
is the status bar.

191
00:09:25,370 --> 00:09:27,810
And so
I can see what I'm viewing right now so

192
00:09:27,810 --> 00:09:29,990
I'm viewing a sequence number right now.

193
00:09:29,990 --> 00:09:34,276
I can see that I've got 327,000 packets,
and I'm displaying,

194
00:09:34,276 --> 00:09:39,760
[LAUGH] 327,000 packet,
if i can read numbers.

195
00:09:39,760 --> 00:09:41,920
I can see dropped, zero.

196
00:09:41,920 --> 00:09:45,453
That means that at no point did my machine
get overloaded and I had to drop packets.

197
00:09:45,453 --> 00:09:47,855
For the amount of time that I monitored,

198
00:09:47,855 --> 00:09:51,397
I captured 100% of what my
computer saw on the network.

199
00:09:51,397 --> 00:09:55,670
All right, now all of this gets gathered
together, it all gets represented

200
00:09:55,670 --> 00:09:59,233
in this user interface,
it's where we spend most of our time.

201
00:09:59,233 --> 00:10:02,680
But there are other
interfaces that you'll see.

202
00:10:02,680 --> 00:10:05,480
So, for example, if you take a packet and

203
00:10:05,480 --> 00:10:08,760
double click on it,
you get a break down window.

204
00:10:08,760 --> 00:10:10,560
Now, what's in the break down window?

205
00:10:10,560 --> 00:10:14,090
The same information that was
in the main window, right?

206
00:10:14,090 --> 00:10:17,700
Except it's taken out the packet list,
cuz now I'm just looking at one packet.

207
00:10:17,700 --> 00:10:22,640
I get the human readable breakdown up here
on the top, and I get the raw output.

208
00:10:22,640 --> 00:10:26,245
This is what the actual packet
contained right here at the bottom, and

209
00:10:26,245 --> 00:10:28,261
it's kinda fun if you go around here and

210
00:10:28,261 --> 00:10:31,640
click It will show you where in
the raw packet that data came from.

211
00:10:31,640 --> 00:10:36,456
So the fact that the source port
was 49,490 was stored right at

212
00:10:36,456 --> 00:10:39,510
the beginning of the packet in the header.

213
00:10:39,510 --> 00:10:43,000
And you can even click around here to
experiment, say well what is this?

214
00:10:43,000 --> 00:10:45,980
Well this was one of
the destination bit values.

215
00:10:45,980 --> 00:10:48,800
These will be things like the source
MAC address and destination.

216
00:10:48,800 --> 00:10:51,040
Yeah, this one's actually
the source MAC address right here.

217
00:10:51,040 --> 00:10:53,890
So you can spot that inside of the packet.

218
00:10:53,890 --> 00:10:57,040
It's all stored right there
if you know how to read it.

219
00:10:57,040 --> 00:10:58,590
The problem is most of us
don't know how to read it.

220
00:10:58,590 --> 00:11:01,740
I don't know exactly which
bits contain what data.

221
00:11:01,740 --> 00:11:06,022
So the interpretation up here
takes that burden away from me.

222
00:11:06,022 --> 00:11:10,080
All right, now on this screen you
don't have to see all this data.

223
00:11:10,080 --> 00:11:12,788
You can customize the layout
however you want and

224
00:11:12,788 --> 00:11:17,345
you'll see a bunch of buttons up here that
let you manipulate that like here we've

225
00:11:17,345 --> 00:11:20,598
got colorize the packets and
auto scroll the packet list.

226
00:11:20,598 --> 00:11:24,278
You can turn those on and off and that
will manipulate the way you know maybe I

227
00:11:24,278 --> 00:11:28,256
don't want those things to be colored but
it is kind of nice to have them colored,

228
00:11:28,256 --> 00:11:30,850
it's different colors for
different activities.

229
00:11:32,240 --> 00:11:36,160
But you can also customize other
things if you go into your view menu.

230
00:11:36,160 --> 00:11:40,120
See how I've got my main toolbar,
filter, and status bar, packet list,

231
00:11:40,120 --> 00:11:42,130
packet details, packet byte.

232
00:11:42,130 --> 00:11:44,250
A lot of times if I'm running this and
I'm running it for

233
00:11:44,250 --> 00:11:47,920
a long period of time, I might just
turn off the packet details and

234
00:11:47,920 --> 00:11:51,340
the packet bytes so
that all I'm seeing is the packet list.

235
00:11:51,340 --> 00:11:51,890
Right?

236
00:11:51,890 --> 00:11:56,900
Now I can start it up and it's running and
I'm just seeing the packet list.

237
00:11:56,900 --> 00:12:00,337
And it's scrolling in real time to
keep the packets up on my screen.

238
00:12:00,337 --> 00:12:04,456
I might turn that off to say don't scroll
in real time, just capture the packets.

239
00:12:04,456 --> 00:12:08,409
This is a pretty low intensity way to
watch it, and I can come in here and

240
00:12:08,409 --> 00:12:11,828
scroll around and
see what's getting recorded and view it.

241
00:12:11,828 --> 00:12:16,522
It does get a bit sluggish because it's
really active doing stuff, and if I want

242
00:12:16,522 --> 00:12:21,233
to see a particular packet, I can find
one, and I can just double-click on it.

243
00:12:21,233 --> 00:12:29,847
And there's the other two panes
of data that I just turned off.

244
00:12:29,847 --> 00:12:34,571
So I still have quick and easy access
to that data if I want to get to it.

245
00:12:34,571 --> 00:12:36,218
And then if I want to turn it back on,
I can always go back up here to View and

246
00:12:36,218 --> 00:12:37,706
turn the packet details and
packet bytes back on whenever I want.

247
00:12:37,706 --> 00:12:38,936
Real easy to manipulate that stuff.

248
00:12:38,936 --> 00:12:42,071
Change the user interface to be
whatever's convenient to you.

249
00:12:42,071 --> 00:12:45,697
When you're troubleshooting you
shouldn't have to fight with software

250
00:12:45,697 --> 00:12:47,880
to get the information you need.

251
00:12:47,880 --> 00:12:49,290
Make this work for you.

252
00:12:51,130 --> 00:12:53,220
All right well,
that's probably enough for this segment.

253
00:12:53,220 --> 00:12:56,764
I do want to go a little more into some of
the neat things we can do with the packets

254
00:12:56,764 --> 00:12:58,077
and capturing of that data.

255
00:12:58,077 --> 00:12:59,098
But let's stop here.

256
00:12:59,098 --> 00:13:02,454
Stay tuned, we've got more videos
coming up on how to use Wireshark.

257
00:13:02,454 --> 00:13:07,736
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Capturing Data
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:05,081
[SOUND] All right at this
point we've seen how to fire

2
00:00:05,081 --> 00:00:10,138
up Wireshark and
we've seen how to get data flowing

3
00:00:10,138 --> 00:00:15,208
into the system to start
capturing those packets.

4
00:00:15,208 --> 00:00:18,004
Now I wanna highlight something
that's really important,

5
00:00:18,004 --> 00:00:20,800
a big mistake that a lot of people make.

6
00:00:20,800 --> 00:00:23,970
When you fire up Wireshark and
you pick your network interface and

7
00:00:23,970 --> 00:00:25,320
you start it recording.

8
00:00:25,320 --> 00:00:26,330
Right?
So off it goes,

9
00:00:26,330 --> 00:00:27,500
it's capturing data on that network.

10
00:00:28,640 --> 00:00:32,270
It's probably not getting all
the data you think it is.

11
00:00:32,270 --> 00:00:32,970
All right?

12
00:00:32,970 --> 00:00:36,650
My laptop is plugged into
the 10.1.230.0 network.

13
00:00:36,650 --> 00:00:39,970
That's the network we
use here in the studio.

14
00:00:39,970 --> 00:00:42,990
And I know that my producer over there,
our director,

15
00:00:42,990 --> 00:00:45,560
some of the others hosts that
are off camera right now.

16
00:00:45,560 --> 00:00:46,950
They've all got their computers fired up.

17
00:00:46,950 --> 00:00:50,220
They're on that 10.1.230 network and
they're browsing the Internet and

18
00:00:50,220 --> 00:00:50,960
doing other things.

19
00:00:52,050 --> 00:00:56,660
So I know they're on the network with me,
and I'm capturing data with Wiresharks so

20
00:00:56,660 --> 00:00:58,480
I'm probably getting their data, right?

21
00:00:58,480 --> 00:01:00,144
Well, probably not.

22
00:01:00,144 --> 00:01:04,420
On a switch based network, which
almost every network is today, right,

23
00:01:04,420 --> 00:01:09,090
on a switch based network,
a switch will take a broadcast and

24
00:01:09,090 --> 00:01:10,860
send it out every port of the switch.

25
00:01:10,860 --> 00:01:13,560
So, yes, I'm seeing all the broadcasts.

26
00:01:13,560 --> 00:01:17,670
But Unicasts, it will look at
the source MAC address, and

27
00:01:17,670 --> 00:01:19,220
the destination MAC address.

28
00:01:19,220 --> 00:01:21,680
And it will send those frames

29
00:01:21,680 --> 00:01:25,280
just to the port that matches
the destination MAC address.

30
00:01:25,280 --> 00:01:31,350
So if my director, Jason, if Jason
is reaching out to Nate's computer,

31
00:01:31,350 --> 00:01:33,730
well, neither of those are my computer.

32
00:01:33,730 --> 00:01:36,630
My Mac address is not the destination
of that communication, so

33
00:01:36,630 --> 00:01:39,440
the switch is never going
to send it to my computer.

34
00:01:39,440 --> 00:01:43,350
Those two computers could be talking
right now and I wouldn't even know it.

35
00:01:44,530 --> 00:01:49,030
So for example, let's do this,
we'll use Jason our director.

36
00:01:49,030 --> 00:01:52,090
Jason could I get you to
fire up the ITProTV page or

37
00:01:52,090 --> 00:01:54,960
if you are already on it just
hit refresh or something.

38
00:01:54,960 --> 00:01:59,750
So I've been capturing for a little while
now, we're at almost 800,000 packets.

39
00:01:59,750 --> 00:02:03,880
And I know for a fact Jason just
went to the ITProTV website.

40
00:02:03,880 --> 00:02:10,640
I'm gonna stop the capture and
I'm gonna search for him, for his stuff.

41
00:02:10,640 --> 00:02:14,390
And there's a few ways to search
you'll see like find a packet,

42
00:02:14,390 --> 00:02:16,050
a little button you can use.

43
00:02:16,050 --> 00:02:20,690
But I like to use filters and we're
gonna do a dedicated video on filters.

44
00:02:20,690 --> 00:02:24,440
But one of the most simple ones is
where you can search for an IP address.

45
00:02:24,440 --> 00:02:29,020
And I know Jason's address,
so that's what I'm gonna do.

46
00:02:29,020 --> 00:02:30,190
He is 10.1.230.5.

47
00:02:30,190 --> 00:02:35,878
So I'm basically saying just show
me the packets that are from or

48
00:02:35,878 --> 00:02:39,720
to 10.1.230.5, okay?

49
00:02:39,720 --> 00:02:43,070
So it's gonna filter through all those
packets that I just captured, and

50
00:02:43,070 --> 00:02:46,980
then it's gonna give me a list of
just the ones that meet my criteria.

51
00:02:46,980 --> 00:02:49,430
So it'll take just a second
cause I captured a lot of stuff.

52
00:02:50,600 --> 00:02:54,490
Now, you might be expecting to see,
oh here's where Jason browsed to ITProTV.

53
00:02:54,490 --> 00:02:56,610
Here's where this happened,
or that happened.

54
00:02:56,610 --> 00:03:00,400
But at the end of the day you'll come
in here and be surprised, right?

55
00:03:00,400 --> 00:03:04,540
So, I see some UDP traffic here,
that's not his web browsing, right?

56
00:03:04,540 --> 00:03:08,100
I see some NBNS, and that's it.

57
00:03:08,100 --> 00:03:13,160
I just see a little tiny handful of
packets from his machine, right?

58
00:03:13,160 --> 00:03:15,800
Let me stretch this out here so
you can see a little better.

59
00:03:15,800 --> 00:03:16,590
This is it.

60
00:03:16,590 --> 00:03:18,350
This is not a lot of packets.

61
00:03:18,350 --> 00:03:20,120
This is just a handful.

62
00:03:21,460 --> 00:03:23,150
It's 15.
If I look down here it says displayed.

63
00:03:23,150 --> 00:03:25,667
I only see 15 packets from Jason.

64
00:03:25,667 --> 00:03:27,620
The source on all of them is 10.1.230.5.

65
00:03:27,620 --> 00:03:30,370
Look at the destinations.

66
00:03:30,370 --> 00:03:34,930
The destination on every
one of them 10.1.230.255.

67
00:03:34,930 --> 00:03:36,990
That's when Jason sent out a broadcast.

68
00:03:36,990 --> 00:03:38,190
I got his broadcast, great!

69
00:03:39,230 --> 00:03:40,920
I didn't get his Unicast.

70
00:03:40,920 --> 00:03:45,530
I only see stuff that came from him,
I don't see what came to him at all.

71
00:03:45,530 --> 00:03:47,770
Because I'm not in that communication.

72
00:03:47,770 --> 00:03:52,280
On a switch based network, you will
not get other people's Unicasts and

73
00:03:52,280 --> 00:03:56,900
that really hinders the functionality of
protocol analyzers like Wireshark, right?

74
00:03:56,900 --> 00:03:59,090
So we need to get around that.

75
00:03:59,090 --> 00:04:00,340
How do we get around that?

76
00:04:00,340 --> 00:04:04,210
Well you could take a hub and
put a hub in between you and

77
00:04:04,210 --> 00:04:05,440
the person you're trying to capture.

78
00:04:05,440 --> 00:04:06,840
That'll work right?

79
00:04:06,840 --> 00:04:08,960
But who's got a hub around anymore, right?

80
00:04:08,960 --> 00:04:11,850
And if you're on a gigabyte network, and
I don't think they even make gig hubs.

81
00:04:11,850 --> 00:04:14,820
So you're already gonna have to take
yourself down to a hundred megs or

82
00:04:14,820 --> 00:04:16,950
ten megs or
something ridiculous like that.

83
00:04:16,950 --> 00:04:18,780
It's just not a viable option.

84
00:04:18,780 --> 00:04:23,270
So if you really wanna leverage your
packet analyzers, you'll need to make

85
00:04:23,270 --> 00:04:27,100
use of other technologies on your switch
to get around that limitation, all right?

86
00:04:27,100 --> 00:04:30,570
Most switches support what's
called port mirroring.

87
00:04:30,570 --> 00:04:34,060
Port mirroring is where you can
take the traffic on one port.

88
00:04:34,060 --> 00:04:36,860
And send a copy of it to another port.

89
00:04:36,860 --> 00:04:39,720
That way you can intercept
communications that

90
00:04:39,720 --> 00:04:42,350
wouldn't normally be sent to your machine,
right?

91
00:04:42,350 --> 00:04:44,950
It does require physical
access to the machine, or at

92
00:04:44,950 --> 00:04:48,130
least administrative access to the switch
to be able to go in and configure it.

93
00:04:48,130 --> 00:04:50,270
And not every switch does it.

94
00:04:50,270 --> 00:04:53,310
But, in an enterprise environment,
almost all of your switches will.

95
00:04:53,310 --> 00:04:55,460
It's a very, very common feature.

96
00:04:55,460 --> 00:04:57,310
They might call it different things.

97
00:04:57,310 --> 00:05:02,400
HP calls it port mirroring, Cisco calls
it SPAN, the Switch Port Analyzer.

98
00:05:02,400 --> 00:05:04,480
So you'll see different names for
the technology.

99
00:05:04,480 --> 00:05:05,630
But it's all the same.

100
00:05:05,630 --> 00:05:10,010
It takes traffic from one port and
copies it to another port.

101
00:05:10,010 --> 00:05:13,420
So if I wanted to get just Jason's
traffic, I can go on the switch,

102
00:05:13,420 --> 00:05:16,510
figure out what port he was plugged
into and mirror his traffic.

103
00:05:16,510 --> 00:05:17,840
But what if I wanted to
get the whole office?

104
00:05:17,840 --> 00:05:20,360
What if I want to get as
much communication as i can?

105
00:05:20,360 --> 00:05:22,110
Well that's a lot harder.

106
00:05:22,110 --> 00:05:24,840
It's really difficult to
capture all the traffic.

107
00:05:24,840 --> 00:05:28,100
You've gotta try and locate some kind
of a bottleneck on your network and

108
00:05:28,100 --> 00:05:30,030
that'll give you the best picture, right?

109
00:05:30,030 --> 00:05:32,330
Maybe there's an uplink
between two switches.

110
00:05:32,330 --> 00:05:34,930
That'll help you get everything
that crosses over the uplink, but

111
00:05:34,930 --> 00:05:37,900
any communications that stay
within a switch you won't see.

112
00:05:37,900 --> 00:05:40,810
So there's not really any
way that you can capture

113
00:05:40,810 --> 00:05:43,390
all the traffic of your whole network.

114
00:05:43,390 --> 00:05:46,410
What I commonly do,
is pick the Internet connection.

00:05:46,410 --> 00:05:48,050

00:05:48,050 --> 00:05:50,780

00:05:50,780 --> 00:05:53,070

So I can go and find those ports on

00:14:14,110 --> 00:14:15,430
And then all they see are broadcast.

287
00:14:15,430 --> 00:14:17,810
And they go man,
our network is broadcast heavy.

288
00:14:17,810 --> 00:14:19,840
We need to do something about that.

289
00:14:19,840 --> 00:14:22,540
Not realizing that,
no you're not broadcast heavy.

290
00:14:22,540 --> 00:14:23,970
It's just that's all you're seeing.

291
00:14:23,970 --> 00:14:26,800
The Unicasts aren't even
coming to your port.

292
00:14:26,800 --> 00:14:28,340
But now I can see these and
I can go through and

293
00:14:28,340 --> 00:14:31,820
start to look at that traffic and
figure out what it is.

294
00:14:31,820 --> 00:14:36,900
I can see that Jason's machine is
a TCP connection to 23.81.44.149.

295
00:14:36,900 --> 00:14:38,630
Well I don't know what that is.

296
00:14:38,630 --> 00:14:41,540
If I had turned the capture option
on to do the DNS look up for that,

297
00:14:41,540 --> 00:14:43,180
it would resolve it and find out.

298
00:14:43,180 --> 00:14:45,200
But that might be ITProTV.

299
00:14:45,200 --> 00:14:46,490
What is our IP address?

300
00:14:49,380 --> 00:14:53,710
Let's do an NSlookup here for ITProTV.

301
00:14:53,710 --> 00:14:59,910
Oh ours is 72.10.35.33 so
that is not you talking to them.

302
00:14:59,910 --> 00:15:02,920
So I can write a more advanced filter
to catch that specific track but

303
00:15:02,920 --> 00:15:06,960
I probably just scan across and find it.

304
00:15:06,960 --> 00:15:08,385
There it is.

305
00:15:08,385 --> 00:15:09,070
72.10.35.44.

306
00:15:09,070 --> 00:15:13,140
There's TCP traffic being sent
between him and that host.

307
00:15:13,140 --> 00:15:15,240
That's him going to the ITProTV site.

308
00:15:15,240 --> 00:15:18,020
Notice right here, HTTP traffic.

309
00:15:18,020 --> 00:15:20,680
And down in the breakdown of the protocol,

310
00:15:20,680 --> 00:15:24,230
I can look and
start to get an idea of what we're seeing.

311
00:15:24,230 --> 00:15:30,150
Here I can see he's doing a get request
and he's asking for slash forums.

312
00:15:30,150 --> 00:15:32,210
Looks like he clicked on
the Q & A link right?

313
00:15:32,210 --> 00:15:33,220
So, is that what you did?

314
00:15:33,220 --> 00:15:35,440
Oh, that's what he did,
he's giving me confirmation over there.

315
00:15:35,440 --> 00:15:40,960
So, he did a GET for slash forums, that's
our Q and A page, and we intercepted.

316
00:15:40,960 --> 00:15:44,680
I can see that GET request and
all the header information for that GET.

317
00:15:44,680 --> 00:15:46,680
So that was the GET request.

318
00:15:46,680 --> 00:15:49,340
If I keep going down,
I should start to see the replies,

319
00:15:49,340 --> 00:15:51,860
the server feeding him that webpage.

320
00:15:51,860 --> 00:15:53,370
So if I look down a little bit further,

321
00:15:53,370 --> 00:15:56,160
I should start to see some of
those replies like this one.

322
00:15:56,160 --> 00:15:59,040
This is just an acknowledgement,
yeah so it doesn't have any payload.

323
00:15:59,040 --> 00:16:00,715
I know it's an acknowledgement
because it tells me.

324
00:16:00,715 --> 00:16:01,480
[LAUGH].

325
00:16:01,480 --> 00:16:04,270
But, if I keep looking down further,
I'll find where there aren't

326
00:16:04,270 --> 00:16:06,830
any acknowledgements,
ones that are actually caring payload.

327
00:16:06,830 --> 00:16:09,100
And it'll have the web page and
all that data.

328
00:16:09,100 --> 00:16:11,700
Now, I have to kind of sift around and
look for it,

329
00:16:11,700 --> 00:16:14,360
because I'm seeing a ton of traffic.

330
00:16:14,360 --> 00:16:16,690
I'm seeing everybody here in the office
as they go out to the internet.

331
00:16:16,690 --> 00:16:18,350
I'm seeing their traffic.

332
00:16:18,350 --> 00:16:19,940
It's all in here.

333
00:16:19,940 --> 00:16:23,090
And that may be a little bit
overwhelming sometimes, right?

334
00:16:23,090 --> 00:16:27,100
If we look, it looks like there
was some kind of a URL rewrite,

335
00:16:28,200 --> 00:16:30,870
and somewhere in here
we'll find the packet.

336
00:16:30,870 --> 00:16:33,895
I'm doing it the hard way here,
visually looking for it.

337
00:16:33,895 --> 00:16:36,820
Wireshark can actually
reassemble these communications.

338
00:16:36,820 --> 00:16:39,230
If you find what you're looking for,

339
00:16:39,230 --> 00:16:41,890
you can tell it to assemble
the path to that communication.

340
00:16:41,890 --> 00:16:45,060
It will show you all the packets that
were involved in that particular string,

341
00:16:45,060 --> 00:16:47,000
and it makes life a lot easier.

342
00:16:47,000 --> 00:16:48,480
But I want to save that for
another episode,

343
00:16:48,480 --> 00:16:51,270
because that's part of the tool set
that we use as we start to troubleshoot

344
00:16:51,270 --> 00:16:52,300
problems.

345
00:16:52,300 --> 00:16:55,870
But this gives you guys a great example
here of how we capture that data.

346
00:16:55,870 --> 00:16:58,976
There's more to it,
than just installing WinPCap, and

347
00:16:58,976 --> 00:17:01,420
telling WireShark to capture data.

348
00:17:01,420 --> 00:17:04,330
We've gotta make sure that our
switch understands we need to see

349
00:17:04,330 --> 00:17:07,540
the information, otherwise we're
not gonna get very far, all right?

350
00:17:07,540 --> 00:17:10,712
So that's a key component
of capturing data.

351
00:17:10,712 --> 00:17:13,490
All right, well stay tuned cause we've got
more videos coming up as we show how to

352
00:17:13,490 --> 00:17:14,820
use some of the more advanced things.

353
00:17:14,820 --> 00:17:17,790
I do wanna show you guys how to
stream together those communications

354
00:17:17,790 --> 00:17:18,560
and filtering.

355
00:17:18,560 --> 00:17:22,110
We need to do a whole episode on filtering
so you understand exactly how you can see

356
00:17:22,110 --> 00:17:26,280
just the information you want, and
not get overwhelmed by the data.

357
00:17:26,280 --> 00:17:27,833
All right.
So stay tuned.

358
00:17:27,833 --> 00:17:29,542
I'll see you in the next video.

359
00:17:29,542 --> 00:17:35,714
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Filtering Packets
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,086
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,086 --> 00:00:09,115
So by this point,

3
00:00:09,115 --> 00:00:13,980
we've already seen how amazing
Wireshark is at gathering this data in.

4
00:00:13,980 --> 00:00:16,430
But you've probably already
noticed how easy it is to get

5
00:00:16,430 --> 00:00:18,490
overwhelmed with the data.

6
00:00:18,490 --> 00:00:20,530
When you start capturing
traffic on a network,

7
00:00:20,530 --> 00:00:25,500
especially a busy network, you're gonna
have hundreds of thousands if not

8
00:00:25,500 --> 00:00:28,870
millions of packets in a very
short amount of time, right?

9
00:00:28,870 --> 00:00:31,290
Let's just take mine as an example.

10
00:00:31,290 --> 00:00:32,660
I'm on a very small network.

11
00:00:32,660 --> 00:00:34,020
I'm on our studio network.

12
00:00:34,020 --> 00:00:37,270
And there are maybe, I'm kind of
looking around the studio here,

13
00:00:37,270 --> 00:00:41,000
there's maybe twelve machines here
on this particular studio network.

14
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:43,670
Now Throughout the building
we've got well over 100, but

15
00:00:43,670 --> 00:00:46,230
on the network that I'm on
there's only about twelve.

16
00:00:46,230 --> 00:00:51,180
And I'm monitoring this particular routers
traffic like we saw on an earlier episode.

17
00:00:51,180 --> 00:00:54,610
And so
I'm not seeing a ton of machines, but

18
00:00:54,610 --> 00:00:58,850
we'll see that this small network
generates a good amount of traffic.

19
00:00:58,850 --> 00:01:00,630
If I go and look at my interfaces here.

20
00:01:00,630 --> 00:01:01,890
I'm gonna monitor this one.

21
00:01:02,990 --> 00:01:05,040
And I'll start up a packet capture here.

22
00:01:05,040 --> 00:01:08,700
So here it's going, and I've just
been running for a few moments, and

23
00:01:08,700 --> 00:01:12,420
down here in my status bar I can see
I've already gathered 5,000 packets.

24
00:01:12,420 --> 00:01:14,760
So in that short amount of time
I've already got 5,000 packets.

25
00:01:14,760 --> 00:01:17,990
And it's starting to grow and
grow as it continues to monitor and

26
00:01:17,990 --> 00:01:22,090
collect data from these systems,
it is impressive, right?

27
00:01:22,090 --> 00:01:24,980
It's a huge amount of data
that it's collecting.

28
00:01:24,980 --> 00:01:29,550
And let me just turn on auto scroll here
so we can see it kinda rattling on by.

29
00:01:29,550 --> 00:01:33,030
In the moment I've stalled there
I'm already at 15 thousand packets.

30
00:01:33,030 --> 00:01:35,860
So this is a huge amount of data.

31
00:01:35,860 --> 00:01:39,100
Well if we're firing up Wireshark
there's normally something in particular

32
00:01:39,100 --> 00:01:40,250
that we're looking for.

33
00:01:40,250 --> 00:01:43,860
I wanna know some particular
piece of information.

34
00:01:43,860 --> 00:01:47,336
Well, how do we find it in all this mess?

35
00:01:47,336 --> 00:01:49,503
I can run a capture like this for
a few moments.

36
00:01:49,503 --> 00:01:52,499
I'm kinda waiting until
I get to 30,000 and

37
00:01:52,499 --> 00:01:57,360
then I'll stop it, and as soon as I
hit 30,000 I'll stop so, there we go.

38
00:01:57,360 --> 00:02:00,360
So now I've got 30,159
packets that I captured.

39
00:02:00,360 --> 00:02:05,920
I want to find out what Jason,
our director, has been doing.

40
00:02:05,920 --> 00:02:08,570
I can see him over here by
the control station, and

41
00:02:08,570 --> 00:02:10,520
I know he's been doing some
stuff over on his machine.

42
00:02:10,520 --> 00:02:12,850
I want to know what he's been doing.

43
00:02:12,850 --> 00:02:14,631
Well, I know his IP address.

44
00:02:14,631 --> 00:02:17,470
His IP address is 10.1.2.30.6.

45
00:02:17,470 --> 00:02:19,678
No, .5.
10.1.2.30.5.

46
00:02:19,678 --> 00:02:21,571
Right.
That's his IP address.

47
00:02:22,690 --> 00:02:23,380
How do I find that?

48
00:02:23,380 --> 00:02:24,840
Well I can scroll around in here.

49
00:02:24,840 --> 00:02:27,080
There's only 30,000 packets, right?

50
00:02:27,080 --> 00:02:31,770
So I can start at the top and just go
down and look for 10.1.2.30.5 right?

51
00:02:31,770 --> 00:02:34,920
Or I can even do a search and
get a little magnifying glass up here.

52
00:02:34,920 --> 00:02:39,480
I can say find a packet and
I'm looking for 10.12.30.5.

53
00:02:39,480 --> 00:02:43,340
But when I start to type that in,
notice how it's red, all right?

54
00:02:43,340 --> 00:02:48,590
Red means whatever I'm putting
in there is not valid, right?

55
00:02:48,590 --> 00:02:53,030
By default, Wireshark is using
a special filter language.

56
00:02:53,030 --> 00:02:56,120
It's got its own little filter language
it uses to allow us to find things.

57
00:02:56,120 --> 00:02:57,680
If I just want to search for that string,

58
00:02:57,680 --> 00:03:00,470
I would need to choose
the string value here.

59
00:03:00,470 --> 00:03:01,970
And then it lights up green.

60
00:03:01,970 --> 00:03:04,330
Now, I can go in and I can search for
this value and I can find it.

61
00:03:05,390 --> 00:03:08,260
The problem with going this way is
it's kind of packet by packet of

62
00:03:08,260 --> 00:03:10,720
finding one after another after another.

63
00:03:10,720 --> 00:03:11,940
And, I'll find weird things too,

64
00:03:11,940 --> 00:03:16,280
like here's one of our Apple devices
that's doing a broadcast, right.

65
00:03:16,280 --> 00:03:18,210
So, it's doing an ARP broadcast.

66
00:03:18,210 --> 00:03:21,210
That's not involving 10.1.230.5, is it?

67
00:03:21,210 --> 00:03:24,648
But if you look at the payload over here,
who has this IP?

68
00:03:24,648 --> 00:03:28,932
Tell 10.1.235 this is an ARP
broadcast that is coming out from

69
00:03:28,932 --> 00:03:33,180
the machine that is actually 10.1.235 so
it found it.

70
00:03:33,180 --> 00:03:35,990
So I could do string searches like that.

71
00:03:35,990 --> 00:03:39,330
But what's better is to do a filter.

72
00:03:39,330 --> 00:03:42,460
Now when we filter in Wireshark
there's two types of filters.

73
00:03:42,460 --> 00:03:46,230
There's a display filter and
there's a capture filter.

74
00:03:46,230 --> 00:03:49,308
A display filter just filters
what we see on screen.

75
00:03:49,308 --> 00:03:52,490
I've captured 30,000 packets.

76
00:03:52,490 --> 00:03:55,975
If I'm looking for a particular set,
I can put a display filter in and

77
00:03:55,975 --> 00:03:59,800
it'll hide the other packets
that don't match my filter.

78
00:03:59,800 --> 00:04:02,360
It doesn't delete them,
it just hides them.

79
00:04:02,360 --> 00:04:03,040
Right?

80
00:04:03,040 --> 00:04:05,800
The alternative is a capture filter.

81
00:04:05,800 --> 00:04:11,550
A capture filter will say only capture
the packets that match my criteria.

82
00:04:11,550 --> 00:04:13,420
And ignore the other ones.

83
00:04:13,420 --> 00:04:17,400
So it's not hiding them, it just doesn't
even log them in the first place.

84
00:04:17,400 --> 00:04:21,540
So, if we're trying to keep our capture
file small, we can use a capture

85
00:04:21,540 --> 00:04:26,600
filter to just block out certain things,
so they don't get logged at all.

86
00:04:26,600 --> 00:04:30,010
Versus a display filter where
we still logged all the packets,

87
00:04:30,010 --> 00:04:32,328
we're just changing which ones we see.

88
00:04:32,328 --> 00:04:33,870
So of 30,000 packets,

89
00:04:33,870 --> 00:04:38,850
if I just wanted to see Jason's machine,
I could write a filter.

90
00:04:38,850 --> 00:04:41,625
Now the filter format is
different unfortunately for

91
00:04:41,625 --> 00:04:42,995
a display in a capture filter.

92
00:04:42,995 --> 00:04:46,155
So there's two different language types
and I wanna show you guys some of the most

93
00:04:46,155 --> 00:04:49,775
common examples of each so you can
recreate this in your own environment.

94
00:04:49,775 --> 00:04:52,545
I'm gonna start with display filters
because they're the ones I use the most

95
00:04:52,545 --> 00:04:56,305
frequently, but capture filters
are the most useful if you're trying to

96
00:04:56,305 --> 00:04:59,970
minimize the data set you're working with,
if you're trying to shrink your log files.

97
00:04:59,970 --> 00:05:02,310
By excluding that you
know is not important.

98
00:05:03,510 --> 00:05:07,850
So if I take these 30,000 packets here and
I just want to see Jason.

99
00:05:07,850 --> 00:05:10,800
Well this is going to be one of
the easiest filters that we write.

100
00:05:10,800 --> 00:05:15,690
I want to filter the traffic to
only show me traffic that involves

101
00:05:15,690 --> 00:05:20,710
a host with the IP address of 10.1.230.5.

102
00:05:20,710 --> 00:05:25,599
Well, I can do ip.source, src.

103
00:05:25,599 --> 00:05:33,310
So ip.src = = 10.1.230.5.

104
00:05:33,310 --> 00:05:34,045
All right.

105
00:05:34,045 --> 00:05:40,003
Show me every packet that has
a source IP address of 10.1.230.5.

106
00:05:40,003 --> 00:05:43,314
As you're typing these filters, you'll
notice it turn red and when it's red,

107
00:05:43,314 --> 00:05:46,990
that means you haven't given it enough
information, or you've got bad syntax.

108
00:05:46,990 --> 00:05:49,530
When you've got a good filter written,
it'll turn green.

109
00:05:49,530 --> 00:05:51,779
So that's an easy way to tell whether
you're writing a good filter.

110
00:05:53,930 --> 00:05:57,120
If you have the filter syntax
memorized you can just type it.

111
00:05:57,120 --> 00:06:00,570
If you don't have it memorized you can
actually hit the expression button.

112
00:06:00,570 --> 00:06:05,175
And when you hit that it brings
up a little wizard type screen,

113
00:06:06,385 --> 00:06:11,905
where you can pick your filters and go
through it this way to pick what you want.

114
00:06:11,905 --> 00:06:15,845
I tend not to do this just
because there's so much in here.

115
00:06:15,845 --> 00:06:19,535
Just look at all the stuff
that you can pick from.

116
00:06:19,535 --> 00:06:25,297
And if I went here under IPv4,
I could find in here under IPv4,

117
00:06:25,297 --> 00:06:30,545
IP.source And let's see.

118
00:06:30,545 --> 00:06:32,330
ip.src right here.

119
00:06:32,330 --> 00:06:34,130
And then is present.

120
00:06:34,130 --> 00:06:36,130
That means it has any value.

121
00:06:36,130 --> 00:06:40,435
Equals equals that means if the IP source
is equal to what I'm about to put in.

122
00:06:40,435 --> 00:06:44,050
!=, that means not equal.

123
00:06:44,050 --> 00:06:49,050
I want to find any traffic where the IP
address does not equal a host, all right?

124
00:06:49,050 --> 00:06:52,170
Or if the IP address is greater or
less than, greater than or equal than,

125
00:06:52,170 --> 00:06:55,280
less than or equal than an IP address
that I provide here, all right?

126
00:06:55,280 --> 00:06:59,886
So you have a lot of control,
and you can specify IP source = =

127
00:06:59,886 --> 00:07:04,240
10.1.230.5 and hit okay and
it'll type it in.

128
00:07:04,240 --> 00:07:07,740
And see how it typed in the same
thing that I had already typed in.

129
00:07:07,740 --> 00:07:12,100
So if you got it memorized it's way faster
then trying to find it in that giant

130
00:07:12,100 --> 00:07:13,280
expression menu.

131
00:07:13,280 --> 00:07:16,620
But the expression menu doesn't give you
an idea of all the different things that

132
00:07:16,620 --> 00:07:20,490
we can filter on, it's incredibly
powerful and it's all right here.

133
00:07:23,770 --> 00:07:26,320
All right, once we've got it in there,
you can hit Apply and

134
00:07:26,320 --> 00:07:28,420
now it's going to filter
what's on your screen.

135
00:07:28,420 --> 00:07:34,544
And now I'm only seeing packets whose
source IP is 10.1.230.5, all right?

136
00:07:34,544 --> 00:07:39,500
And down here at the bottom of the screen
I can see I've got 30,159 packets.

137
00:07:39,500 --> 00:07:46,690
But I'm only displaying 2775 which
accounts for 8.5% of my total packets.

138
00:07:46,690 --> 00:07:48,660
So now I'm just seeing
what I'm looking for.

139
00:07:50,100 --> 00:07:53,010
Maybe I want to see traffic
that's going to Jason's machine.

140
00:07:53,010 --> 00:07:57,792
So I can go in here and
change that source to destination, DST.

141
00:07:57,792 --> 00:08:01,260
All right, then I can go ahead and
hit apply.

142
00:08:01,260 --> 00:08:03,635
And now it's going to
reverse that filter and

143
00:08:03,635 --> 00:08:06,710
now I'm only seeing traffic
with a destination of his IP.

144
00:08:06,710 --> 00:08:08,770
All right?

145
00:08:08,770 --> 00:08:12,710
What if I want to see both,
traffic to him and from him?

146
00:08:12,710 --> 00:08:14,990
I want to see all the communications
from his machine.

147
00:08:14,990 --> 00:08:16,400
All right?

148
00:08:16,400 --> 00:08:19,830
Well, in that scenario,
we can change this just a little bit.

149
00:08:19,830 --> 00:08:25,029
Instead of saying source or
destination, you can say IP Address.

150
00:08:25,029 --> 00:08:26,698
IP.ADDR.

151
00:08:26,698 --> 00:08:29,020
All right, now I'm saying,

152
00:08:29,020 --> 00:08:34,600
show me packets that involve this
address as a source or a destination.

153
00:08:34,600 --> 00:08:39,970
So when we run that,
now I'll see full conversations with him.

154
00:08:39,970 --> 00:08:42,630
Packets going to him, and
packets coming from him.

155
00:08:42,630 --> 00:08:48,340
And you'll see these mapped together
like he's talking to 23.81.44.149.

156
00:08:48,340 --> 00:08:51,970
And getting replies right, so all those
communications are right here; and

157
00:08:51,970 --> 00:08:53,800
I can get an idea what's going on.

00:08:53,800 --> 00:08:57,158
I see he's got some RTMP traffic going on,
so he's watching a video stream...

00:08:57,158 --> 00:09:00,135
Probably us,
right; Our live video stream I imagine.

00:09:00,135 --> 00:09:02,430
[LAUGH] He's giving me

00:09:02,430 --> 00:09:05,810
Or he could be [LAUGH] All right,

00:09:05,810 --> 00:09:09,205
I won't do the hand gesture
that he just gave me but.

00:09:09,205 --> 00:09:10,400

164
00:09:10,400 --> 00:09:13,938
So we can start to see that traffic and

165
00:09:13,938 --> 00:09:17,280
Now, that IP.addr.

166
00:09:17,280 --> 00:09:19,350
What that is, is that's actually an alias.

167
00:09:19,350 --> 00:09:21,870
It's an alias for doing two queries.

168
00:09:21,870 --> 00:09:27,440
It's doing a query for
IP source of 10.1.230.5.

169
00:09:27,440 --> 00:09:32,150
And IP destination 10.1.230.5, all right?

170
00:09:32,150 --> 00:09:34,190
This is the short-hand
method of writing it.

171
00:09:34,190 --> 00:09:37,030
We could write it long-hand
if we wanted to, all right?.

172
00:09:37,030 --> 00:09:41,910
If I wanted to write it out longer, we
could write this a slightly different way.

173
00:09:41,910 --> 00:09:48,966
We could say ip.source = 10.1.230.5 or

174
00:09:48,966 --> 00:09:55,232
ip.destination = 10.1.230.5.

175
00:09:55,232 --> 00:10:02,020
Show me any packet whose source
is 10.1.230.5 or destination.

176
00:10:03,390 --> 00:10:08,225
When I apply that,
it's the same exact same as if I had done

177
00:10:08,225 --> 00:10:13,110
IP.ADDR but I wanted to show you this so
you can see that or operator.

178
00:10:13,110 --> 00:10:17,770
When I say or, now I'm giving it
multiple criteria that can be matched

179
00:10:17,770 --> 00:10:21,280
to help me isolate exactly what
it is that I'm looking for.

180
00:10:21,280 --> 00:10:24,110
Be careful with this because you
might be tempted to say and.

181
00:10:24,110 --> 00:10:28,757
Show me packets that have
a source of 10.1.230.5 and

182
00:10:28,757 --> 00:10:30,660
a destination of 10.1.230.5.

183
00:10:30,660 --> 00:10:36,000
Well the only time I would see that is if
Jason is talking to himself, all right?

184
00:10:36,000 --> 00:10:40,290
Then the source and
the destination would both be 10.1.230.5.

185
00:10:40,290 --> 00:10:45,910
So we're more commonly going to use or
if the source is this,

186
00:10:45,910 --> 00:10:48,400
or the destination is that.

187
00:10:48,400 --> 00:10:52,110
All right, so
those are some examples of some filters.

188
00:10:52,110 --> 00:10:54,310
Don't forget that we can do the not equal.

189
00:10:54,310 --> 00:11:00,150
I can say if the IP source
is not equal to 10.1.230.5.

190
00:11:00,150 --> 00:11:04,230
Or the destination is not equal
to 10.1.230.5 show me that.

191
00:11:04,230 --> 00:11:07,550
This is how we start to exclude people.

192
00:11:07,550 --> 00:11:10,010
Maybe I don't wanna see
traffic from Jason.

193
00:11:10,010 --> 00:11:13,460
I wanna see all of the other traffic,
and so

194
00:11:13,460 --> 00:11:15,800
if I apply that it's gonna filter it out.

195
00:11:15,800 --> 00:11:19,780
And now I can see I have 30,159 packets.

196
00:11:19,780 --> 00:11:24,542
And it's only displaying 20,790, and
apparently I've written it wrong.

197
00:11:24,542 --> 00:11:25,150
Oh shoot!

198
00:11:25,150 --> 00:11:27,656
I forgot!
I've gotta do some parentheses on

199
00:11:27,656 --> 00:11:28,480
this one.

200
00:11:28,480 --> 00:11:32,670
See how I've got some packets that
actually include some Jason 10.1.230.5.

201
00:11:32,670 --> 00:11:34,380
All right, and

202
00:11:34,380 --> 00:11:38,460
that's because this packet it's actually
matching off of this first one.

203
00:11:38,460 --> 00:11:41,870
Its source is not 10.1.230.5,
and so it's displaying it.

204
00:11:41,870 --> 00:11:44,140
So this is a slight problem.

205
00:11:44,140 --> 00:11:45,510
Let me show you how we
can work around that.

206
00:11:46,710 --> 00:11:50,870
Okay, sometimes the filters require
a little bit of finesse to get it working.

207
00:11:50,870 --> 00:11:56,780
Remember when I did it this way,
when I did the == like this.

208
00:11:56,780 --> 00:11:59,520
I did get just traffic involving Jason.

209
00:11:59,520 --> 00:12:01,130
8349 packets, and that's it.

210
00:12:01,130 --> 00:12:02,300
Right?
If I want

211
00:12:03,640 --> 00:12:08,500
to exclude both of these criteria,
well, you don't want to do

212
00:12:08,500 --> 00:12:12,150
the 'not equal' right here inside of
the criteria with an 'or' statement.

213
00:12:12,150 --> 00:12:16,715
It causes the problem that
I just had Instead what you

214
00:12:16,715 --> 00:12:20,878
wanna do is put the whole
thing in parentheses.

215
00:12:20,878 --> 00:12:21,410
Right?
So

216
00:12:21,410 --> 00:12:26,460
I'm gonna stick some parentheses at the
beginning and at the end of the filter.

217
00:12:28,480 --> 00:12:29,490
All right?

218
00:12:29,490 --> 00:12:31,830
And once I've got those
parentheses at the beginning and

219
00:12:31,830 --> 00:12:35,820
end, I'm gonna add the exclamation point
right there at the very beginning.

220
00:12:35,820 --> 00:12:36,460
Okay?

221
00:12:36,460 --> 00:12:39,070
So I'm saying filter traffic.

222
00:12:39,070 --> 00:12:44,070
I want traffic to not have
a source of 10.1.235 or

223
00:12:44,070 --> 00:12:47,650
a source of 10.1.230.5, so
that's gonna do it proper.

224
00:12:47,650 --> 00:12:51,720
The negation is actually being outside
of the or statement, all right?

225
00:12:51,720 --> 00:12:57,683
When we apply that, now I should see,
sure enough, now I've got 30,000 packets.

226
00:12:57,683 --> 00:13:04,430
21,810 are being displayed and I don't
see any here that match Jason's IP.

227
00:13:04,430 --> 00:13:05,240
All right.

228
00:13:05,240 --> 00:13:08,980
I do see a lot of IPv6 stuff,
but nothing that matches Jason.

229
00:13:08,980 --> 00:13:13,880
So, writing a proper filter might take
you a few tries to get that syntax

230
00:13:13,880 --> 00:13:14,910
quite right.

231
00:13:14,910 --> 00:13:16,060
Just be careful.

232
00:13:16,060 --> 00:13:19,630
When you're doing equal equals, those
are pretty safe pretty much all the time.

233
00:13:19,630 --> 00:13:22,470
But when you're doing not equals,
when you're doing negations or

234
00:13:22,470 --> 00:13:24,700
exclusions, it can get a little tricky.

235
00:13:24,700 --> 00:13:28,260
And you may have to use parentheses like
this to handle that exclusion properly.

236
00:13:28,260 --> 00:13:32,290
All right, now filtering by IP is one
thing is one thing we might do but

237
00:13:32,290 --> 00:13:34,430
filtering but protocol is another one.

238
00:13:34,430 --> 00:13:37,590
So we can filter a few
different ways by protocol.

239
00:13:37,590 --> 00:13:40,960
Maybe I just want to see web traffic.

240
00:13:40,960 --> 00:13:45,070
So I could say TCP.port, == 80.

241
00:13:45,070 --> 00:13:49,130
Show me any traffic where
the TCP port is 80.

242
00:13:49,130 --> 00:13:52,190
That's going to be
unencrypted wed traffic.

243
00:13:52,190 --> 00:13:55,540
And if I apply that It's gonna run and

244
00:13:55,540 --> 00:13:58,140
now I'll see any time
somebody's browsing the web.

245
00:13:58,140 --> 00:14:00,060
Right.
Filtering by that protocol.

246
00:14:00,060 --> 00:14:03,430
You'll find a lot of protocols
actually have an alias name put in.

247
00:14:03,430 --> 00:14:07,140
And so sometimes you can punch in,
== http.

00:14:07,140 --> 00:14:09,590
Right?
But in this scenario it's not working.

00:14:09,590 --> 00:14:12,750
So if it stays red then it doesn't have
it and you can type in a port number.

00:14:12,750 --> 00:14:15,700
I've kind of gotten in the habit
of typing in a port number because

00:14:15,700 --> 00:14:16,840
I know those always work.

252
00:14:16,840 --> 00:14:18,750
The alias names don't always work.

253
00:14:18,750 --> 00:14:20,950
In fact,
there is something a little bit quirky.

254
00:14:20,950 --> 00:14:24,670
Let's say that I wanted to see
unencrypted and encrypted web traffic.

255
00:14:24,670 --> 00:14:27,620
I wanted port 80 and port 443.

256
00:14:27,620 --> 00:14:28,710
Well, watch this.

257
00:14:28,710 --> 00:14:33,090
If I say TCP.port == 80 or

00:14:33,090 --> 00:14:36,544
TCP port == 443,

259
00:14:36,544 --> 00:14:42,850
alright that works for me and
if I apply that, there we go.

260
00:14:42,850 --> 00:14:47,650
And now I'm seeing unencrypted web
traffic as well as encrypted web

261
00:14:47,650 --> 00:14:50,140
traffic as two separate statements.

262
00:14:50,140 --> 00:14:52,490
But there is actually a way
that we can combine these.

263
00:14:52,490 --> 00:14:54,150
Let's see do I have an example of that?

264
00:14:54,150 --> 00:14:56,530
I may not have an example of that one.

265
00:14:58,440 --> 00:15:01,330
I'll show you an example a little bit
later when we get into the capture filters

266
00:15:01,330 --> 00:15:02,770
where these can be a problem.

267
00:15:02,770 --> 00:15:05,680
But as long as we're separating them
with or statements it's not a big deal.

268
00:15:05,680 --> 00:15:09,170
In the capture situation there's a part
where we won't use that or statement and

269
00:15:09,170 --> 00:15:10,590
it causes a bit of a problem.

270
00:15:10,590 --> 00:15:13,310
But here we do that filter and
it's catching it and

271
00:15:13,310 --> 00:15:14,250
it's knocking it right out.

272
00:15:15,580 --> 00:15:18,150
Alright, other types of
filters that we might do.

273
00:15:18,150 --> 00:15:20,650
Let's see that was
an example of a TCP port.

274
00:15:20,650 --> 00:15:22,520
Where are some other examples?

275
00:15:24,890 --> 00:15:30,040
Let's see oh, alright so,
if we say on this filter,

276
00:15:30,040 --> 00:15:34,560
we just go real simple like this and
we just type in filter http.

277
00:15:34,560 --> 00:15:35,940
All right.

278
00:15:35,940 --> 00:15:40,360
When you run that, it will filter
it out and just show that protocol.

00:15:40,360 --> 00:15:46,640
So, I didn't even have to type in
TCP.protocol, whatever TCP.port = 80.

280
00:15:46,640 --> 00:15:48,711
You can just type in the protocol and

281
00:15:48,711 --> 00:15:51,418
if it's got an alias name
it will pull that up.

282
00:15:51,418 --> 00:15:56,332
So if I'm just looking for
that RTMP traffic I can apply it, and
