00:15:56,332 --> 00:15:57,833
it won't find it.

284
00:15:57,833 --> 00:16:02,157
[LAUGH] So apparently that
one didn't work for me, but

285
00:16:02,157 --> 00:16:07,840
I guess the rtnp traffic is UDP so
it's probably not happy about that.

286
00:16:07,840 --> 00:16:11,440
I was doing tcp port but you also have udp
port other filters that are like that for

287
00:16:11,440 --> 00:16:15,630
being able to go in there and locate
whatever it is that you're looking for.

288
00:16:15,630 --> 00:16:19,220
Now I filtered based on protocol,
and I filtered based on IP.

289
00:16:19,220 --> 00:16:23,890
You can also filter based on a network,
like an entire subnet if you want.

290
00:16:23,890 --> 00:16:30,160
so you could say a range
of IPs if you wanted.

291
00:16:30,160 --> 00:16:36,550
When you do that IP source, you can
specify in subnet notation, 10.1.230.0/24,

292
00:16:36,550 --> 00:16:42,880
and then you would just see traffic that's
originating from inside of your network.

293
00:16:44,740 --> 00:16:46,970
That's useful for a few reasons.

294
00:16:46,970 --> 00:16:51,580
If you're monitoring a trunc, and
a trunc is carrying multiple VLANs and

295
00:16:51,580 --> 00:16:55,610
multiple subnets, you might wanna limit
yourself down to just one VLAN's traffic,

296
00:16:55,610 --> 00:16:57,650
and this is just one way to go about that.

297
00:16:59,180 --> 00:17:00,370
Let's see what else do I have?

298
00:17:00,370 --> 00:17:01,330
I think that's about it.

299
00:17:01,330 --> 00:17:03,800
Let's see different port numbers,
we talked about negation,

300
00:17:03,800 --> 00:17:05,550
we saw port filters.

301
00:17:05,550 --> 00:17:09,050
Yeah, so as far as display filters go,
those are the main ones,

302
00:17:09,050 --> 00:17:11,120
those are the ones that I
typically work with right there.

303
00:17:11,120 --> 00:17:14,690
And those are ones that I just got
memorized, so their quick and easy to use.

304
00:17:14,690 --> 00:17:18,350
But, there's a ton more, you can
filter based on darn near everything.

305
00:17:19,540 --> 00:17:23,470
But all the filters I just
showed you were display filters.

306
00:17:23,470 --> 00:17:23,980
All right?

307
00:17:23,980 --> 00:17:25,960
They're just filtering what
shows up here on screen.

308
00:17:25,960 --> 00:17:30,650
If I clear the filter out, I still have
30,000 packets that are sitting there.

309
00:17:30,650 --> 00:17:32,110
Okay?

310
00:17:32,110 --> 00:17:36,000
If I want to minimize
the size of my capture,

311
00:17:36,000 --> 00:17:40,450
if I'm on a really busy network and I
just can't possibly capture all the data.

312
00:17:40,450 --> 00:17:43,390
Then we can do a Capture Filter to stop

313
00:17:43,390 --> 00:17:46,830
packets from even making it into
our capture in the first place.

314
00:17:46,830 --> 00:17:50,050
With those we set them up
when we start a new capture.

315
00:17:50,050 --> 00:17:54,440
So, I'm gonna go up here
to my capture options.

316
00:17:54,440 --> 00:17:59,310
And in my capture options screen I'll
see where I can put in a capture filter.

317
00:17:59,310 --> 00:18:01,300
Just like a display filter
I can click on that and

318
00:18:01,300 --> 00:18:03,860
I've got all the different things
that I can filter on, but notice.

319
00:18:03,860 --> 00:18:05,360
It's a much smaller list.

320
00:18:05,360 --> 00:18:09,070
I don't have as much power
with Capture Filter.

321
00:18:09,070 --> 00:18:14,210
So you'll see I can use like TCP or
UDP only, particular IP addresses.

322
00:18:14,210 --> 00:18:15,850
They give you a lot of examples here.

323
00:18:15,850 --> 00:18:18,120
You can filter based on a Mac address.

324
00:18:18,120 --> 00:18:20,240
There's all sorts of
neat things you can do.

325
00:18:20,240 --> 00:18:22,970
And they're basically giving
you the syntax right here

326
00:18:22,970 --> 00:18:26,480
that you would use to create that filter,
all right?

327
00:18:26,480 --> 00:18:30,200
But I'll just type out a few
here to give you some examples.

328
00:18:30,200 --> 00:18:34,360
Let's say that I wanted to
get a particular host, right?

329
00:18:34,360 --> 00:18:39,560
Well what I would type is host 10.1.230.5.

330
00:18:39,560 --> 00:18:41,240
And now when I run this capture,

331
00:18:41,240 --> 00:18:45,080
it is just going to get
traffic from that one host.

332
00:18:45,080 --> 00:18:49,420
And if I start that up, right,
here it goes capturing.

333
00:18:49,420 --> 00:18:53,030
And, sure, I'm getting a lot of data,
but look at it all.

334
00:18:53,030 --> 00:18:57,390
It's all either from or
to Jason's computer.

335
00:18:57,390 --> 00:19:00,320
There's other traffic being
generated on the network.

336
00:19:00,320 --> 00:19:01,170
I'm ignoring it.

337
00:19:01,170 --> 00:19:02,920
I'm throwing it out.

338
00:19:02,920 --> 00:19:06,170
So all that other traffic is
not even making it into my log.

339
00:19:06,170 --> 00:19:09,470
That helps to keep the log files
a lot more succinct, right.

340
00:19:09,470 --> 00:19:11,691
They're not full of all this extra data.

341
00:19:16,276 --> 00:19:17,066
All right.

342
00:19:17,066 --> 00:19:18,526
Some of the other filters
that I could have used.

343
00:19:18,526 --> 00:19:19,361
That was a host.

344
00:19:19,361 --> 00:19:20,400
I could have done a network.

345
00:19:20,400 --> 00:19:23,980
You could do net 10.1.230.0/24.

346
00:19:23,980 --> 00:19:27,285
When I do that, that's saying,
throw out any other networks.

347
00:19:27,285 --> 00:19:30,885
I don't wanna get anything else, just give
me traffic dealing with this network right

348
00:19:30,885 --> 00:19:35,965
here and keep my log files small.

349
00:19:35,965 --> 00:19:40,755
When we do this, when we do net or
host, it defaults to both directions.

350
00:19:40,755 --> 00:19:43,405
So it's giving traffic to and
from that network.

351
00:19:43,405 --> 00:19:49,380
But you can do source and destination if
you want, so you could say dst.net, right?

352
00:19:49,380 --> 00:19:51,380
Or dst host.

353
00:19:51,380 --> 00:19:54,690
Or you could say src.net or src host.

354
00:19:54,690 --> 00:19:58,490
That way you're just getting the source,
the data coming from that host.

355
00:19:58,490 --> 00:20:00,950
Or destination, data going to that host.

356
00:20:00,950 --> 00:20:02,910
So you can be really specific if you want.

357
00:20:02,910 --> 00:20:05,580
But when you just do net or
host, it's bi-directional.

358
00:20:05,580 --> 00:20:07,840
It's getting traffic to and
from that particular person.

359
00:20:09,990 --> 00:20:14,130
We can also do other things like,
like we can say Port 80 right?

360
00:20:14,130 --> 00:20:16,750
Just give me traffic on TCP port 80,

361
00:20:16,750 --> 00:20:18,910
that's going to be
unencrypted web traffic.

362
00:20:20,410 --> 00:20:22,670
We can say, we can be really specific.

363
00:20:22,670 --> 00:20:25,300
Port 80 that'll get TCP and UDP.

364
00:20:25,300 --> 00:20:30,010
But if I say TCP port 80, then that's
gonna give me just the TCP traffic, and

365
00:20:30,010 --> 00:20:30,860
not UDP.

366
00:20:30,860 --> 00:20:34,733
So really starting to shrink down
the traffic that we're gonna get.

367
00:20:34,733 --> 00:20:39,233
If I want to monitor something like SIP,
I could say UDP port 5060.

368
00:20:39,233 --> 00:20:39,733
Right.

369
00:20:39,733 --> 00:20:43,836
That's SIP for voice over IP
communications, It doesn't use TCP or

370
00:20:43,836 --> 00:20:45,650
at least not normally.

371
00:20:45,650 --> 00:20:47,580
And it uses UDP for the communications.

372
00:20:47,580 --> 00:20:51,370
So now I'll be able to capture that.

373
00:20:51,370 --> 00:20:52,170
All right.

374
00:20:52,170 --> 00:20:53,780
You can combine multiple ports.

375
00:20:53,780 --> 00:20:58,020
So we could say, like,
port 80 or 443, right?

376
00:20:59,020 --> 00:21:00,040
So now it's gonna get both.

377
00:21:00,040 --> 00:21:02,350
I wanna get just web traffic in general,
80 or 443,

378
00:21:02,350 --> 00:21:05,970
and when I fire that up,
now it's gonna capture that.

379
00:21:05,970 --> 00:21:09,786
And I'm getting it for all hosts,
I didn't put a host filter on there, but

380
00:21:09,786 --> 00:21:11,858
it's gonna reach out and get that data.

381
00:21:14,370 --> 00:21:16,139
Now, when we do a display filter,

382
00:21:16,139 --> 00:21:20,690
the display filter we use the exclamation
point to negate things for exclusions.

383
00:21:20,690 --> 00:21:23,460
In a capture filter you use the word not.

384
00:21:23,460 --> 00:21:26,510
So you can say not host whatever.

385
00:21:26,510 --> 00:21:28,700
So maybe I want to exclude myself.

386
00:21:28,700 --> 00:21:30,316
I don't want a log traffic coming from me.

387
00:21:30,316 --> 00:21:35,025
So I might say not host 10.1.230.243,
all right?

388
00:21:35,025 --> 00:21:37,275
I'm on the capture station.

389
00:21:37,275 --> 00:21:39,580
So I don't need to capture
my own traffic and in fact,

390
00:21:39,580 --> 00:21:41,470
that can kind of bog the system down.

391
00:21:41,470 --> 00:21:43,810
I'm streaming my desktop out
to you guys right now so

392
00:21:43,810 --> 00:21:46,040
all that stream traffic
is gonna show up there.

393
00:21:46,040 --> 00:21:52,976
So I could say not host 10.1.230.243 or

394
00:21:52,976 --> 00:21:55,950
I could say not port.

395
00:21:55,950 --> 00:21:59,890
Oh shoot,
I don't remember our TMP's port number.

396
00:21:59,890 --> 00:22:01,566
But I can add on to it and say.

397
00:22:01,566 --> 00:22:05,983
Oh, I guess it would be orb,
nor port, or TMP.

398
00:22:05,983 --> 00:22:08,030
If I knew its port number
I could put that in there.

399
00:22:08,030 --> 00:22:09,650
But you could specify that and

400
00:22:09,650 --> 00:22:13,970
add additional criteria to start stacking
it together to exclude that traffic out.

401
00:22:13,970 --> 00:22:16,810
So it just doesn't even make
it into the capture at all.

402
00:22:16,810 --> 00:22:17,400
All right.

403
00:22:17,400 --> 00:22:21,290
And so, when I run that, now I'm going to
be capturing traffic on the network, but

404
00:22:21,290 --> 00:22:27,850
not traffic from my own machine,
keeping it clean.

405
00:22:27,850 --> 00:22:28,760
All right.

406
00:22:28,760 --> 00:22:30,460
Some other examples we might do.

407
00:22:31,780 --> 00:22:35,260
Well here, we'll take like my
screen capture example, right?

408
00:22:35,260 --> 00:22:39,070
So I said not host 10.1.230.243.

409
00:22:39,070 --> 00:22:42,010
My software on my laptop that's
streaming on my desktop,

410
00:22:42,010 --> 00:22:43,691
it's actually using two ports.

411
00:22:43,691 --> 00:22:49,172
So I could add to this and say,

412
00:22:49,172 --> 00:22:55,751
let's do and not port 49001 or

413
00:22:55,751 --> 00:22:59,275
port 49002.

414
00:22:59,275 --> 00:23:02,958
Okay, so now it's gonna say,
any traffic from that host,

415
00:23:02,958 --> 00:23:06,862
we're gonna drop off if it's
from that host and it's, well,

416
00:23:06,862 --> 00:23:10,210
actually I wouldn't
want to do a not there.

417
00:23:10,210 --> 00:23:10,910
There.

418
00:23:10,910 --> 00:23:15,650
So if it's from this host,
and it's on these ports,

419
00:23:15,650 --> 00:23:18,500
one of these two ports,
then we'll exclude it.

420
00:23:18,500 --> 00:23:20,540
You see how this starts
to get a little complex,

421
00:23:20,540 --> 00:23:23,590
you start to combine all these different
elements and it gets confusing.

422
00:23:23,590 --> 00:23:27,310
But now I would still get traffic from
my host as long as it wasn't on one

423
00:23:27,310 --> 00:23:30,190
of these two ports,
the ports that I'm using for streaming.

424
00:23:30,190 --> 00:23:33,290
That would lop that off and
again keep my capture small.

425
00:23:33,290 --> 00:23:35,756
Now again, if you're only running
a capture for a few minutes,

426
00:23:35,756 --> 00:23:39,066
you probably don't care about Capture
Filters, you'll just use display filters.

427
00:23:39,066 --> 00:23:41,830
But if you want to run a capture for
24 hours and

428
00:23:41,830 --> 00:23:44,191
capture a very specific set of traffic.

429
00:23:44,191 --> 00:23:46,708
Capture filters will help to make
sure that you don't run out of

430
00:23:46,708 --> 00:23:49,870
hard drive space or run out of RAM
while you're running your capture.

431
00:23:49,870 --> 00:23:51,160
So they're pretty important.

432
00:23:51,160 --> 00:23:55,090
You're actively discarding the packets
that don't match your filter.

433
00:23:55,090 --> 00:23:58,340
Whatever you're excluding in your filter
is not going to get logged at all.

434
00:23:58,340 --> 00:23:59,660
It's gonna get thrown away and

435
00:23:59,660 --> 00:24:02,560
you'll just be left with
the information you actually need.

436
00:24:03,960 --> 00:24:11,370
All right, one last one that I like to
use is not broadcast and not multicast.

437
00:24:12,450 --> 00:24:14,950
There, when we do a capture,

438
00:24:14,950 --> 00:24:17,660
a lot of times we're concerned
about unicasts, right?

439
00:24:17,660 --> 00:24:21,030
Broadcasts can be useful if you're trying
to locate like viruses that are scanning

440
00:24:21,030 --> 00:24:22,210
your network or whatever.

441
00:24:22,210 --> 00:24:26,590
But typically broadcast and multicast
is not going to give you what you want.

442
00:24:26,590 --> 00:24:28,590
And so
we can punch that into block those out.

443
00:24:29,960 --> 00:24:30,780
I'll do that.

444
00:24:30,780 --> 00:24:33,090
And so now I'm capturing
traffic on my network but

445
00:24:33,090 --> 00:24:37,079
I'm knocking out those broadcasts and I'm
just seeing unicast between the sheets.

446
00:24:38,300 --> 00:24:41,390
So those are some of the examples
of filters that we can use.

447
00:24:41,390 --> 00:24:44,170
The filter language is not too
terribly intuitive because there's

448
00:24:44,170 --> 00:24:45,170
two different languages.

449
00:24:45,170 --> 00:24:47,590
One for display filter,
one for capture filter.

450
00:24:47,590 --> 00:24:50,630
So just remember if you forget the syntax

451
00:24:50,630 --> 00:24:52,970
that you can always rely
on the expression button.

452
00:24:52,970 --> 00:24:56,490
In the display filter,
you'll see you've got a ton of power.

453
00:24:56,490 --> 00:25:01,400
In the Capture Filter, not as much,
but you do have a decent bit to

454
00:25:01,400 --> 00:25:03,880
be able to go in, and they give you
some examples you can build off of.

455
00:25:03,880 --> 00:25:08,660
And then you can go on and modify them
right down here to match your needs, okay?

456
00:25:08,660 --> 00:25:10,790
So take advantage of
the Expressions button.

457
00:25:10,790 --> 00:25:15,110
It's pretty helpful to be able
to get some examples on the fly.

458
00:25:15,110 --> 00:25:16,040
All right.

459
00:25:16,040 --> 00:25:17,530
So that pretty much wraps up filtering.

460
00:25:17,530 --> 00:25:19,310
That'll give you a better
handle on your data.

461
00:25:19,310 --> 00:25:22,460
So it is an important skill
to have with Wireshark.

462
00:25:22,460 --> 00:25:23,270
We sure to stay tuned.

463
00:25:23,270 --> 00:25:26,380
We've got some other videos coming up with
more advanced Wireshark features, but

464
00:25:26,380 --> 00:25:27,480
I hope you guys enjoy this one.

465
00:25:27,480 --> 00:25:31,125
I'll see you next time.

466
00:25:31,125 --> 00:25:35,950
[NOISE]

episodes.title: Assembling a Conversation
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:07,729
[SOUND] So
once we start capturing packets,

2
00:00:07,729 --> 00:00:12,870
we got a lot of data in there.

3
00:00:12,870 --> 00:00:15,580
And the majority of those packets
are related to each other, right.

4
00:00:15,580 --> 00:00:20,460
When two machines communicate, they rarely
communicate with just single packets.

5
00:00:20,460 --> 00:00:24,310
Most networks have a maximum transmission
unit, MTU, of about 1,500 bytes.

6
00:00:25,310 --> 00:00:29,460
So if you're sending more than
1,500 bytes, it's gotta break it up

7
00:00:29,460 --> 00:00:31,850
into multiple frames to be able
to send it on the network.

8
00:00:31,850 --> 00:00:33,600
And those then get
reassembled into packets.

9
00:00:33,600 --> 00:00:35,110
So we see that.

10
00:00:35,110 --> 00:00:37,490
Things are being reassembled,
we get the packets on our screen.

11
00:00:37,490 --> 00:00:40,070
That's what we see here.

12
00:00:40,070 --> 00:00:43,930
But some communications like Telnet and
other protocols you're sending keystrokes.

13
00:00:43,930 --> 00:00:46,800
They're very small, and
each one fits in a single packet.

14
00:00:46,800 --> 00:00:49,830
And so your communication then
gets broken up into many,

15
00:00:49,830 --> 00:00:52,520
many packets just because
it's not very large.

16
00:00:52,520 --> 00:00:54,890
And you're sending them at certain times.

17
00:00:54,890 --> 00:01:00,750
So how can we string all of that
together to form an entire conversation?

18
00:01:00,750 --> 00:01:03,290
The conversation is when two hosts
are talking to each other and

19
00:01:03,290 --> 00:01:04,680
exchanging information.

20
00:01:04,680 --> 00:01:07,580
And one packet by itself
might not be very useful.

21
00:01:07,580 --> 00:01:12,180
But if we have the entire set of packets,
we can actually reassemble

22
00:01:12,180 --> 00:01:15,080
that communication and
do some pretty neat things.

23
00:01:15,080 --> 00:01:17,292
Let me show you an example
of how that works.

24
00:01:17,292 --> 00:01:20,130
I'm gonna run a capture here and
I'm just gonna capture my laptop.

25
00:01:20,130 --> 00:01:23,490
So I'm doing a capture
filter to tie just to me.

26
00:01:23,490 --> 00:01:25,440
And I'll start that up, all right.

27
00:01:25,440 --> 00:01:29,300
So here I'm capturing just the traffic
coming from my laptop, and

28
00:01:29,300 --> 00:01:31,180
then I'm gonna do something bad, right.

29
00:01:31,180 --> 00:01:35,700
I'm gonna fire up a non secure and
unencrypted protocol like Telnet.

30
00:01:35,700 --> 00:01:38,890
So I'm gonna jump over here
to a terminal window, and

31
00:01:38,890 --> 00:01:42,040
I'm gonna Telnet to a host on the network.

32
00:01:42,040 --> 00:01:45,765
And this is a Cisco switch
that I'm Telneting into, and

33
00:01:45,765 --> 00:01:49,820
I'll provide my username, and
I'll provide my password.

34
00:01:51,730 --> 00:01:52,820
So I'll just punch that in there.

35
00:01:52,820 --> 00:01:56,150
So here I am, I'm in the switch.

36
00:01:56,150 --> 00:01:59,190
And now I can do a show version, and

37
00:01:59,190 --> 00:02:02,140
take a look at what version
of the software I'm running.

38
00:02:02,140 --> 00:02:05,850
I can do a show IP interface brief.

39
00:02:05,850 --> 00:02:08,570
And start to take a look at
the interfaces that are on this switch,

40
00:02:08,570 --> 00:02:13,040
I can start to do all my work,
so there I go very exciting.

41
00:02:13,040 --> 00:02:14,460
I'm working the switch and I get out.

42
00:02:14,460 --> 00:02:19,100
Now I know Telnet is
a non encrypted protocol.

43
00:02:19,100 --> 00:02:22,570
So I know all that traffic went
across the network in plain text.

44
00:02:22,570 --> 00:02:26,773
And if I come back here and I look, and
I can see all those packets right here,

45
00:02:26,773 --> 00:02:30,000
because you know I'm limiting
it down to just my laptop.

46
00:02:30,000 --> 00:02:32,660
And so when I look [LAUGH] I've
got a couple of things going on.

47
00:02:32,660 --> 00:02:36,250
It looks like Dropbox is
synchronizing in the background.

48
00:02:36,250 --> 00:02:41,050
That's always good, but then we see some
other junk going on and as we scroll down,

49
00:02:41,050 --> 00:02:43,810
I think I went a little too far.

50
00:02:43,810 --> 00:02:47,760
Let me stop the thing.

51
00:02:47,760 --> 00:02:51,720
So if I go back in here and
look, I can find Telnet.

52
00:02:51,720 --> 00:02:53,080
There's the Telnet communications.

53
00:02:53,080 --> 00:02:54,270
All right, and in fact,

54
00:02:54,270 --> 00:02:57,880
if I put a filter in here and
tell it just to show me Telnet.

55
00:02:57,880 --> 00:03:00,990
Now I'm just seeing that Telnet
communication that we did.

56
00:03:02,100 --> 00:03:03,180
And so I can take a look at that.

57
00:03:03,180 --> 00:03:04,910
Now you saw what I did.

58
00:03:04,910 --> 00:03:10,800
And if we look here we can see it's
actually broken up into 193 packets.

59
00:03:10,800 --> 00:03:14,530
So my communication with the switch,
when I logged in, and

60
00:03:14,530 --> 00:03:18,790
I ran those few commands, was 193 packets.

61
00:03:18,790 --> 00:03:20,410
Now if I was a patient man.

62
00:03:20,410 --> 00:03:22,910
I could go through and
look at each one of these.

63
00:03:22,910 --> 00:03:26,170
And find the information that happened.

64
00:03:26,170 --> 00:03:28,818
All right, I can see the communication in
fact you can kind of see it starting in

65
00:03:28,818 --> 00:03:29,350
some of these.

66
00:03:29,350 --> 00:03:30,750
If you look at the raw data down here.

67
00:03:30,750 --> 00:03:33,350
I see X term 256 colors.

68
00:03:33,350 --> 00:03:37,940
That's me negotiating out the protocol
to connect with for that console.

69
00:03:37,940 --> 00:03:42,680
And as we go down, somewhere in here we'll
find where it prompts for a username and

70
00:03:42,680 --> 00:03:43,230
password.

71
00:03:43,230 --> 00:03:44,400
Those will be in here.

72
00:03:44,400 --> 00:03:46,580
There we go, so
here it's prompting for a password.

73
00:03:46,580 --> 00:03:48,450
I see password:.

74
00:03:48,450 --> 00:03:53,490
And here this is gonna
be me responding back.

75
00:03:53,490 --> 00:03:56,950
Now when I was typing my password,
I typed one letter at a time.

76
00:03:56,950 --> 00:04:00,960
And with each letter it was
sent to the other side.

77
00:04:00,960 --> 00:04:01,820
And log.

78
00:04:01,820 --> 00:04:04,070
Well this is the first letter, right here.

79
00:04:04,070 --> 00:04:05,120
The letter D.

80
00:04:05,120 --> 00:04:06,520
And here's the second letter.

81
00:04:06,520 --> 00:04:07,430
The letter O.

82
00:04:07,430 --> 00:04:08,270
And the third letter.

83
00:04:08,270 --> 00:04:09,400
The letter M.

84
00:04:09,400 --> 00:04:11,440
Each one, right here in these packets.

85
00:04:11,440 --> 00:04:15,120
And if I was patient, I could go through
each one of these and figure it out.

86
00:04:15,120 --> 00:04:17,512
But Wireshark can do it for me.

87
00:04:17,512 --> 00:04:18,630
With Wireshark,

88
00:04:18,630 --> 00:04:23,540
you can take any one packet in a TCP
stream, you can right click on it,

89
00:04:23,540 --> 00:04:28,210
and you'll see where you've got an option
right here to follow the TCP stream.

90
00:04:28,210 --> 00:04:30,530
This is also under
the Analyze menu up top.

91
00:04:30,530 --> 00:04:34,673
If you go under Analyze, you'll see follow
TCP stream there, it's the same thing.

92
00:04:34,673 --> 00:04:37,720
And what it'll do is it will look
at the packet you selected, and

93
00:04:37,720 --> 00:04:41,500
then it will look at all of
the packets in that communication, and

94
00:04:41,500 --> 00:04:45,350
assemble them together in
a full communication, and

95
00:04:45,350 --> 00:04:49,530
just show you the payload, not headers and
all that other junk, just the payload.

96
00:04:49,530 --> 00:04:52,300
And so that's what I wanna do,
I'm gonna take this packet.

97
00:04:52,300 --> 00:04:55,760
I'll choose to follow the stream and
it's gonna reassemble.

98
00:04:55,760 --> 00:04:58,140
And look what we see now, right.

99
00:04:58,140 --> 00:05:01,220
Now I can read this as if
it was really happening.

100
00:05:01,220 --> 00:05:05,350
What's in red,
red is what I sent to the switch.

101
00:05:05,350 --> 00:05:08,200
What's in blue is what
the switch sent to me.

102
00:05:08,200 --> 00:05:11,820
So when I logged in the switch
sent me this login banner.

103
00:05:12,840 --> 00:05:14,310
Unauthorized access is not permitted.

104
00:05:14,310 --> 00:05:15,190
Access verification.

105
00:05:15,190 --> 00:05:17,050
And it prompted for a username.

106
00:05:17,050 --> 00:05:19,224
And then I sent it a username.

107
00:05:19,224 --> 00:05:21,530
Well notice my username: it was DPezet,

108
00:05:21,530 --> 00:05:24,990
you guys saw me type it on the screen,
why are the letters there twice?

109
00:05:24,990 --> 00:05:28,270
Well I sent it,
the letter D, that's in red,

110
00:05:28,270 --> 00:05:33,070
and then it sent back the letter
D to show it on the screen.

111
00:05:33,070 --> 00:05:34,690
I saw it as I typed it, right.

112
00:05:34,690 --> 00:05:35,960
It's echoing.

113
00:05:35,960 --> 00:05:38,150
When I typed the password,
it didn't do that though.

114
00:05:38,150 --> 00:05:42,590
I sent it my password and
it did not echo it back on the screen.

115
00:05:42,590 --> 00:05:46,610
So I just see my password
donttasemebro right there, right.

116
00:05:46,610 --> 00:05:47,980
So, there's my password.

117
00:05:47,980 --> 00:05:49,613
That's our Florida humor
we get to throw in.

118
00:05:49,613 --> 00:05:53,282
So [LAUGH] and we've got that one there,
and I can read that password.

119
00:05:53,282 --> 00:05:54,929
It was sent across
the network in plain text.

120
00:05:54,929 --> 00:05:59,441
Now this was 190,
actually 304 packets now, so

121
00:05:59,441 --> 00:06:02,580
it was 304 packets in this stream,

122
00:06:02,580 --> 00:06:07,220
it has reassembled that all and
I can just read it.

123
00:06:07,220 --> 00:06:09,100
I logged in, I ran show version.

124
00:06:09,100 --> 00:06:13,380
Now for echo commands, it get's kind of
annoying seeing the double up like that,

125
00:06:13,380 --> 00:06:18,120
so down here,
we can choose some different filters

126
00:06:18,120 --> 00:06:20,700
to change the direction that
we're seeing and so on.

127
00:06:20,700 --> 00:06:25,540
And actually you know what in the,
in the Windows version you can choose.

128
00:06:25,540 --> 00:06:27,680
Oh yeah, here we go, so
in the Mac version we can too.

129
00:06:27,680 --> 00:06:29,660
Here I'm on entire conversation and

130
00:06:29,660 --> 00:06:33,762
if we drop that down you can choose to
see one direction versus the other.

131
00:06:33,762 --> 00:06:37,982
I'm gonna tell it just to show me stuff
that the switch was sending, 10.1.10.2.

132
00:06:37,982 --> 00:06:41,360
And that's gonna filter out the commands
that I saw and make it easier for

133
00:06:41,360 --> 00:06:42,500
me to read.

134
00:06:42,500 --> 00:06:47,120
And now when I go through,
I can see, they ran show version and

135
00:06:47,120 --> 00:06:48,830
here's the output for show version.

136
00:06:48,830 --> 00:06:49,590
Now I know.

137
00:06:50,700 --> 00:06:52,540
What iOS that switch is running.

138
00:06:52,540 --> 00:06:55,690
And then after that we ran
show IP interface brief.

139
00:06:55,690 --> 00:06:57,330
And then here's the output for that.

140
00:06:57,330 --> 00:06:59,400
And you'll get a little bit
of a screen mess up here,

141
00:06:59,400 --> 00:07:02,140
because we've got more prompts, and
then you hit space bar to make it go on so

142
00:07:02,140 --> 00:07:03,740
it kind of throws it off a little bit.

143
00:07:03,740 --> 00:07:06,520
But there's that output plain as day.

144
00:07:06,520 --> 00:07:09,920
That entire session has been reassembled.

145
00:07:09,920 --> 00:07:12,270
If we do this when somebody
is browsing to a webpage,

146
00:07:12,270 --> 00:07:16,260
we'll see the HTML codes of that
page reassembled right here.

147
00:07:16,260 --> 00:07:17,710
This is the page they went to.

148
00:07:17,710 --> 00:07:20,130
You can see the links and so on.

149
00:07:20,130 --> 00:07:21,860
It's really powerful stuff.

150
00:07:21,860 --> 00:07:26,040
It makes it a lot easier than trying
to piece this together ourselves.

151
00:07:26,040 --> 00:07:26,930
We just let Wireshark do it.

152
00:07:27,960 --> 00:07:31,140
And when it comes to FTP, Telnet, right.

153
00:07:31,140 --> 00:07:32,490
Unencrypted protocols.

154
00:07:32,490 --> 00:07:36,390
We can get a full session payload,
and not only know what they did, but

155
00:07:36,390 --> 00:07:37,250
have access to it.

156
00:07:37,250 --> 00:07:38,880
The files, the images, all that stuff.

157
00:07:38,880 --> 00:07:41,210
We can reassemble that and
have access to it.

158
00:07:41,210 --> 00:07:44,720
With encrypted traffic,
it's not so useful, right.

159
00:07:44,720 --> 00:07:46,882
Let me show you an example
of encrypted traffic.

160
00:07:46,882 --> 00:07:50,689
I'm gonna clear out my filter, and
let me just start this over again.

161
00:07:50,689 --> 00:07:54,492
All right, and
this time I'm gonna go back here and

162
00:07:54,492 --> 00:07:58,212
instead of using Telnet,
this time I'll do SSH.

163
00:07:58,212 --> 00:08:01,421
And I'm gonna connect right
back to that same switch,

164
00:08:01,421 --> 00:08:05,604
I'm gonna login as dpezet, see I sent
in my login name right there, and

165
00:08:05,604 --> 00:08:09,472
I'll punch in that same password,
donttasemebro, all right.

166
00:08:09,472 --> 00:08:11,162
And I'll run show version.

167
00:08:11,162 --> 00:08:13,720
All right.

168
00:08:13,720 --> 00:08:16,750
And I'll run show IP interface brief.

169
00:08:16,750 --> 00:08:19,777
So I'm doing the exact same
thing I did with Telnet.

170
00:08:22,505 --> 00:08:23,340
And then I'll get out.

171
00:08:25,100 --> 00:08:25,740
All right.

172
00:08:25,740 --> 00:08:31,610
So the same as I did with Telnet, If I go
back here and I look, here's that stream.

173
00:08:31,610 --> 00:08:37,480
See all this SSH version two traffic,
and I can filter that out, so I just see

174
00:08:37,480 --> 00:08:42,330
the SSH version two,
which apparently it doesn't have.

175
00:08:43,600 --> 00:08:48,730
All right, well, we'll do TCP port = 22.

176
00:08:48,730 --> 00:08:49,650
There.
Alright.

177
00:08:49,650 --> 00:08:52,120
So now I'm just seeing the SSH traffic.

178
00:08:52,120 --> 00:08:53,780
So here it is, this is my SSH session.

179
00:08:54,910 --> 00:08:56,890
But SSH is encrypted.

180
00:08:56,890 --> 00:08:58,520
So when I look at the payload down here.

181
00:08:58,520 --> 00:09:00,130
Remember on Telnet when
I looked at the payload,

182
00:09:00,130 --> 00:09:04,450
I could actually see the word password or
user name or whatever.

183
00:09:04,450 --> 00:09:07,060
Here I just see junk on each one of these.

184
00:09:07,060 --> 00:09:10,480
Actually one of them, will have text
in it where it describes the encryption

185
00:09:10,480 --> 00:09:12,310
protocols that are supported.

186
00:09:12,310 --> 00:09:15,600
But other than that,
everything else is gonna be encrypted.

187
00:09:15,600 --> 00:09:18,930
All right, since it's encrypted,
there's not anything I can get out of it.

188
00:09:18,930 --> 00:09:23,635
And if I right click on that, and I do
like follow TCP stream, it will try and

189
00:09:23,635 --> 00:09:24,700
reassemble it.

190
00:09:24,700 --> 00:09:25,520
Here's that header part,

191
00:09:25,520 --> 00:09:29,100
we're showing all the encryption
protocols that are supported.

192
00:09:29,100 --> 00:09:33,180
And then after that, it goes encrypted.

193
00:09:33,180 --> 00:09:35,270
It's still reassembling it for
me, here it is.

194
00:09:35,270 --> 00:09:37,530
This is the communication.

195
00:09:37,530 --> 00:09:39,270
But it's a bit of a mess, isn't it?

196
00:09:39,270 --> 00:09:40,890
And I don't know what's going on.

197
00:09:40,890 --> 00:09:44,950
Here, I ran some command,
I don't know what, right.

198
00:09:44,950 --> 00:09:49,140
Was that me running show version,
was that me running show IP interface.

199
00:09:49,140 --> 00:09:51,490
Was that me pressing space bar
to get more on the screen.

200
00:09:51,490 --> 00:09:54,550
I have no idea because
it's fully encrypted.

201
00:09:54,550 --> 00:09:58,050
So following the TCP steam of
an encrypted communication

202
00:09:58,050 --> 00:10:00,070
is not terribly useful, right.

203
00:10:00,070 --> 00:10:04,620
But like any stream its got sequence
numbers, we can piece this stuff together.

204
00:10:04,620 --> 00:10:05,370
And it tries.

205
00:10:05,370 --> 00:10:07,630
Now some of this it's having to guess on,

206
00:10:07,630 --> 00:10:11,020
because the sequence number
in an encrypted packet

207
00:10:11,020 --> 00:10:14,900
is not necessarily the sequence number for
the data that's inside of that packet.

208
00:10:14,900 --> 00:10:19,700
If it's running in tunnel mode, then the
sequence numbers don't mean anything, and

209
00:10:19,700 --> 00:10:22,670
so we could be assembling something
here that's completely unrelated data.

210
00:10:22,670 --> 00:10:26,000
I could be sending two completely
separate sets of data to that server, and

211
00:10:26,000 --> 00:10:28,690
we're merging them here because
we can't tell the difference.

212
00:10:28,690 --> 00:10:31,780
If this was like a VPN in
transport mode though,

213
00:10:31,780 --> 00:10:33,030
the sequence numbers mean something.

214
00:10:33,030 --> 00:10:35,570
And now I would know that this
was the right set of data.

215
00:10:35,570 --> 00:10:38,320
So depending on the data people
are sending, we may or may not be able to

216
00:10:38,320 --> 00:10:43,300
reassemble it, but unencrypted traffic, we
can piece together that communication, and

217
00:10:43,300 --> 00:10:47,800
actually strip out the payload using
that follow TCP stream, all right.

218
00:10:47,800 --> 00:10:52,120
You've also got follow UDP stream and
even follow SSL streams, but again,

219
00:10:52,120 --> 00:10:55,160
the SSL stream's not terribly useful
unless you have the private key to be able

220
00:10:55,160 --> 00:10:55,810
to decrypt it.

221
00:10:55,810 --> 00:10:58,380
Now if you're monitoring your own network,
and

222
00:10:58,380 --> 00:11:01,780
you've got that private key,
then that can be useful to you, right.

223
00:11:01,780 --> 00:11:04,480
So that's why the option is included here,
all right.

224
00:11:04,480 --> 00:11:06,160
But that's a really cool
way to go in there and

225
00:11:06,160 --> 00:11:09,390
take a look at that to break into,
not necessarily break in.

226
00:11:09,390 --> 00:11:13,490
But to break out that data and take
a look at it in a more meaningful manner,

227
00:11:13,490 --> 00:11:15,460
in a conversational manner.

228
00:11:15,460 --> 00:11:17,700
By stringing it all together.

229
00:11:17,700 --> 00:11:19,720
All right.
Well, I hope you guys enjoyed that.

230
00:11:19,720 --> 00:11:22,147
Stay tuned.
We've got more videos on Wireshark coming

231
00:11:22,147 --> 00:11:24,395
up, and
we've got a lot more features to cover.

232
00:11:24,395 --> 00:11:26,535
So hope to see you then.

233
00:11:26,535 --> 00:11:32,904
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Statistics and Reporting
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,087
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,257 --> 00:00:10,820
So you've just performed a capture.

3
00:00:10,820 --> 00:00:13,180
You've got a ton of data.

4
00:00:13,180 --> 00:00:15,940
Now where do you get started, right.

5
00:00:15,940 --> 00:00:17,890
A lot of times when we're running
Wireshark, we're looking for

6
00:00:17,890 --> 00:00:21,670
something in particular, but sometimes
we don't know exactly what that is.

7
00:00:21,670 --> 00:00:24,250
For example,
maybe my network is running slow.

8
00:00:24,250 --> 00:00:28,070
I know that I've got a good gigabit
network, or hundred megabit network or

9
00:00:28,070 --> 00:00:31,270
something like that, and for some reason
I'm just not getting that throughput.

10
00:00:31,270 --> 00:00:35,440
So I assume somebody else is
consuming traffic on the network.

11
00:00:35,440 --> 00:00:36,500
Who is it?

12
00:00:36,500 --> 00:00:38,920
How do I start to find
that information out?

13
00:00:38,920 --> 00:00:42,390
How much bandwidth is my network
currently consuming and so on?

14
00:00:42,390 --> 00:00:45,770
Well, Wireshark contains
an entire set of statistics and

15
00:00:45,770 --> 00:00:48,440
reporting utilities that can
give you that information.

16
00:00:48,440 --> 00:00:51,130
That can let you compare
host communications and

17
00:00:51,130 --> 00:00:55,980
quickly isolate who is
the primary user on your network.

18
00:00:55,980 --> 00:00:59,190
From there you can start to write filters
to capture just that person's traffic and

19
00:00:59,190 --> 00:01:00,460
isolate what it is.

20
00:01:00,460 --> 00:01:04,150
So to get a starting point,
we normally start with the statistics and

21
00:01:04,150 --> 00:01:05,990
reporting inside of Wireshark.

22
00:01:06,990 --> 00:01:10,560
Most of this is buried
under the Statistics menu.

23
00:01:10,560 --> 00:01:13,880
If you drop it down you'll see a lot
information here to be able to generate

24
00:01:13,880 --> 00:01:19,210
charts and graphics that relate to what's
going on on your network, all right?

25
00:01:19,210 --> 00:01:22,140
I'm gonna go over some of the most common
ones, but there are a ton in here, so

26
00:01:22,140 --> 00:01:24,310
take advantage of what you've got.

27
00:01:24,310 --> 00:01:27,230
But if we start right here at the top,
we've got the Summary.

28
00:01:27,230 --> 00:01:29,970
The Summary screen is not terribly
useful in my opinion, but

29
00:01:29,970 --> 00:01:34,060
basically what it does is it takes
the capture that you've gathered, and

30
00:01:34,060 --> 00:01:39,140
gives you some overall highlights,
like how much data is in the capture.

31
00:01:39,140 --> 00:01:42,947
I can see down here, you know, some basic
information about the capture that I did.

32
00:01:42,947 --> 00:01:47,760
I captured 139,000 packets,
and I'm displaying them all.

33
00:01:47,760 --> 00:01:49,020
I didn't have any drops.

34
00:01:49,020 --> 00:01:50,400
All right.
I got everything in.

35
00:01:50,400 --> 00:01:53,400
The average packet size, was 1,003 bytes.

36
00:01:53,400 --> 00:01:57,789
Sorry, the average packets
per second was 1,003.

37
00:01:57,789 --> 00:02:01,660
My average packet size was only 860 bytes.

38
00:02:01,660 --> 00:02:03,916
So even though my MTU
might be much higher,

39
00:02:03,916 --> 00:02:05,995
the average size is actually smaller.

40
00:02:05,995 --> 00:02:10,995
The bytes that I got in total,
I can see that during that

41
00:02:10,995 --> 00:02:16,560
time that I was monitoring,
I got 119 megabytes of data.

42
00:02:16,560 --> 00:02:18,760
So not a whole heck of a lot in there.

43
00:02:18,760 --> 00:02:21,730
And my average megabit
per second was only 6.9.

44
00:02:21,730 --> 00:02:26,130
So on average during this operation,
my network was at just 6.9 megabits.

45
00:02:26,130 --> 00:02:28,770
Now I might have spiked much
higher during that time.

46
00:02:28,770 --> 00:02:31,500
I might have dropped down to
nothing during that time.

47
00:02:31,500 --> 00:02:34,340
But this is just that overall summary,
all right.

48
00:02:34,340 --> 00:02:37,250
If that's what you're looking for,
this screen is pretty useful.

49
00:02:37,250 --> 00:02:41,080
But if you're trying to find a culprit
this doesn't really help much.

50
00:02:41,080 --> 00:02:43,420
So it's here, we can use it.

51
00:02:43,420 --> 00:02:46,530
I don't typically go to it too often.

52
00:02:46,530 --> 00:02:47,810
Slightly more useful screens,

53
00:02:47,810 --> 00:02:51,120
if you go under Statistics
you've got Protocol Hierarchy.

54
00:02:52,200 --> 00:02:56,060
Protocol Hierarchy will analyze
all the packets you captured.

55
00:02:56,060 --> 00:02:59,260
And break out the traffic
based on protocol,

56
00:02:59,260 --> 00:03:02,790
what type of traffic was
consuming most of your bandwidth?

57
00:03:02,790 --> 00:03:05,810
And it will lay it out for you right here
on the screen, so I can look at mine and

58
00:03:05,810 --> 00:03:07,200
I can see.

59
00:03:07,200 --> 00:03:08,740
Kind of what was happening, and

60
00:03:08,740 --> 00:03:15,210
if we kinda shrink some of these items
down to make it a little more explorable.

61
00:03:15,210 --> 00:03:17,680
There's no like quick
breakdown button on these.

62
00:03:19,060 --> 00:03:21,270
But if we kinda collapse
a lot of this data down,

63
00:03:21,270 --> 00:03:23,870
you can get a higher level view,
and it makes a little more sense.

64
00:03:23,870 --> 00:03:27,080
I can see that 100% of
my traffic were frames.

65
00:03:27,080 --> 00:03:27,815
I expect that.

66
00:03:27,815 --> 00:03:30,290
100% of my traffic was ethernet.

67
00:03:30,290 --> 00:03:33,190
I'm not running token ring or anything
else like that on this network, so

68
00:03:33,190 --> 00:03:34,590
everything was ethernet.

69
00:03:34,590 --> 00:03:39,414
And then I can see IP version 6
accounted for 22% of my traffic,

70
00:03:39,414 --> 00:03:43,380
IP version 4 accounted for
77% of my traffic.

71
00:03:43,380 --> 00:03:47,940
So almost a quarter was IPv6,
but the bulk was IPv4.

72
00:03:47,940 --> 00:03:50,840
You've got other things in here like ARP,
LLC,

73
00:03:50,840 --> 00:03:56,170
LLDP but there were almost negligible just
a handful of packets for each of those.

74
00:03:56,170 --> 00:04:01,600
But just inside of here I can break this
down and see more about this traffic.

75
00:04:01,600 --> 00:04:04,030
Now IPv4 77% of my traffic, that's great.

76
00:04:04,030 --> 00:04:06,730
Maybe I look at this and go,
you know what, I'm not running IPV6,

77
00:04:06,730 --> 00:04:09,740
how is that consuming 22% of my traffic?

78
00:04:09,740 --> 00:04:10,330
Why is that?

79
00:04:10,330 --> 00:04:11,540
You can start to break it down.

80
00:04:11,540 --> 00:04:16,680
I am using IPv6 to stream my desktop so
that's likely going to be this one.

81
00:04:16,680 --> 00:04:20,130
If I go in here I can see the TCP
traffic accounting for all of it.

82
00:04:20,130 --> 00:04:24,180
And inside of there I can see
most of that was data, and

83
00:04:24,180 --> 00:04:26,910
then looks like there's some
unaccounted for information.

84
00:04:26,910 --> 00:04:27,649
It just kind of disappears.

85
00:04:27,649 --> 00:04:34,580
I've got my TCP at 22.39% of my packets,
but only at 15.98% of it was data.

86
00:04:34,580 --> 00:04:35,655
The other, it's gone.

87
00:04:35,655 --> 00:04:37,640
It's just not here in the list.

88
00:04:37,640 --> 00:04:40,240
That is one of the problems with
these summaries, sometimes they don't

89
00:04:40,240 --> 00:04:43,190
have menu entires for certain types
of information and it gets excluded.

90
00:04:43,190 --> 00:04:44,570
So that's exactly what's happening here.

91
00:04:45,860 --> 00:04:49,240
If I break up that IPv4 data, though,
this one will be a a little more advanced.

92
00:04:49,240 --> 00:04:53,170
I can see that RTMP, the Real Time
Messaging Protocol, accounted for

93
00:04:53,170 --> 00:04:54,070
10% of my traffic.

94
00:04:54,070 --> 00:04:54,850
That's our stream,

95
00:04:54,850 --> 00:04:58,880
the live stream, if you're watching
this live, it's what you use.

96
00:04:58,880 --> 00:05:04,000
I can see SSL was another 7%,
plain test HTTP was only .7%.

97
00:05:04,000 --> 00:05:06,760
So we're doing secure browsing apparently.

98
00:05:06,760 --> 00:05:11,850
But you can break that even further
down and see JPEG, HTML, JavaScript.

99
00:05:11,850 --> 00:05:14,990
Laying it out based on what
was consuming the bandwidth.

100
00:05:14,990 --> 00:05:17,570
And we get bandwidth in terms of
just the percentage of packets,

101
00:05:17,570 --> 00:05:20,710
which is really our throughput,
and percentage of bytes, so

102
00:05:20,710 --> 00:05:24,559
our actual size of our traffic, and
you can break it down from there.

103
00:05:25,680 --> 00:05:28,110
So it's a really useful way of seeing

104
00:05:28,110 --> 00:05:31,320
who was the main traffic
consumer in terms of protocols.

105
00:05:32,570 --> 00:05:36,150
But it not normally the protocols we
care about so much as it is the host.

106
00:05:36,150 --> 00:05:36,710
Which host?

107
00:05:36,710 --> 00:05:40,650
Which machine wasn't on my network that
was actually consuming the bandwidth?

108
00:05:40,650 --> 00:05:42,560
The protocol hierarchy
doesn't tell me that, right?

109
00:05:42,560 --> 00:05:46,410
It tells me the protocols but
not who did it, right?

110
00:05:46,410 --> 00:05:47,970
So if we wanna know who did it.

111
00:05:47,970 --> 00:05:50,288
That's what we need endpoints.

112
00:05:50,288 --> 00:05:53,170
I need endpoints to know
who was the machine,

113
00:05:53,170 --> 00:05:55,980
the actual computer that
used this bandwidth.

114
00:05:55,980 --> 00:06:00,550
And if we go back under
Statistics you'll see Endpoints.

115
00:06:00,550 --> 00:06:05,660
And if we go to Endpoints now it's
gonna give me a list of computers.

116
00:06:05,660 --> 00:06:07,300
And it's breaking it down by protocol.

117
00:06:07,300 --> 00:06:11,350
So it starts with ethernet, and notice
how there's just 40 endpoints there.

118
00:06:11,350 --> 00:06:14,785
And then I've got IPv4 where there's 206,

119
00:06:14,785 --> 00:06:19,230
IPv6 where there's 18, TCP 648, UDP 256.

120
00:06:19,230 --> 00:06:22,600
It's breaking it down by
the protocols that it found.

121
00:06:22,600 --> 00:06:24,760
If a protocol is not lit up like IPX.

122
00:06:24,760 --> 00:06:29,000
That means that we just didn't have any
packets that were in that protocol.

123
00:06:29,000 --> 00:06:31,290
So we can go in and
we can start to locate this.

124
00:06:31,290 --> 00:06:35,190
My Mac address is one-way, you can see all
of our various systems that are out there.

125
00:06:35,190 --> 00:06:40,970
We've got Dells and [INAUDIBLE],
I wonder what that is,

126
00:06:40,970 --> 00:06:44,690
LG, Samsung, we've got all sorts of
different hosts that are on our network.

127
00:06:44,690 --> 00:06:47,655
A lot of Apple, apparently we've
gotten a little Apple heavy.

128
00:06:47,655 --> 00:06:50,170
[LAUGH] But we can start to
see all that If we go to IPv4,

129
00:06:50,170 --> 00:06:52,960
we can get the breakdown by IP.

130
00:06:52,960 --> 00:06:56,490
And if I sort it up here,
I can start to see some of that traffic.

131
00:06:56,490 --> 00:07:00,900
Normally, I'm not gonna sort by IP,
I'm gonna sort by either bytes or packets.

132
00:07:00,900 --> 00:07:04,740
Who sent me the most packets is not
always gonna match up with who sent

133
00:07:04,740 --> 00:07:05,900
the most bytes.

134
00:07:05,900 --> 00:07:07,890
So you may see some differences there.

135
00:07:07,890 --> 00:07:14,111
But I can see the bulk of my traffic
was being generated by 10.1.230.30.

136
00:07:14,111 --> 00:07:16,850
Okay, they generated
the bulk of my traffic

137
00:07:16,850 --> 00:07:19,520
at about 27 megs during this capture.

138
00:07:19,520 --> 00:07:21,860
So, not terribly large amount of data.

139
00:07:21,860 --> 00:07:23,400
But they were the one that was up top.

140
00:07:24,680 --> 00:07:27,614
Now, who is 10.1.230.30.

141
00:07:27,614 --> 00:07:30,760
I don't know, I'd have to go and
do a reverse name lookup.

142
00:07:30,760 --> 00:07:32,730
I've got a set to do name resolution, but

143
00:07:32,730 --> 00:07:35,960
it apparently wasn't able to find
a reverse lookup on that one.

144
00:07:35,960 --> 00:07:40,100
So, I don't necessarily know who that is.

145
00:07:40,100 --> 00:07:41,990
I need to go and find out on my network.

146
00:07:41,990 --> 00:07:46,163
I also see a lot of traffic
from 168.61.129.78.

147
00:07:46,163 --> 00:07:46,862
Who is that?

148
00:07:46,862 --> 00:07:47,540
Well, again, I don't know.

00:07:51,898 --> 00:07:53,135

00:07:53,773 --> 00:07:59,300

00:08:47,830 --> 00:08:50,770

00:08:50,770 --> 00:08:56,415

00:08:56,415 --> 00:08:58,312

00:08:58,312 --> 00:09:00,335

168.61.129.78.

00:09:02,640 --> 00:09:05,490

00:09:05,490 --> 00:09:09,910
Host A talking to B and

00:09:09,910 --> 00:09:17,130
So, bytes from A to B was pretty high,

00:09:17,130 --> 00:09:21,748

00:09:27,720 --> 00:09:32,750

And then I can go down and

Unfortunately in this case,

I can go and find 10.1.230.30,

Maybe I've got security cameras

But the conversation list

That's how we can start to find out

All right, now, with the endpoints, and

When I went to Endpoints,

If I went under Statistics and Endpoint

00:11:21,510 --> 00:11:24,540

00:11:24,540 --> 00:11:28,030

00:11:28,030 --> 00:11:28,960

If you're dealing with

Now, that may be useful to you.

So
